=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Having watched Tom Vassle review this game, I had a lot riding on Munchkin. Either I loved it and lost respect for Toms greatly balanced reviews, which in turn cast a shadow of doubt over all other reviews he makes in the future, or I disliked the game and agreed wholeheartedly that there's no real substance or longevity to the series.

Sadly, I believe the huge series to be simply a license to print money. The original Munchkin has the thicker cards and all subsequent expansions, which I also played, were of a thinner cheaper card, but yet still share the same sale price. So I conclude it's the biggest rip off I've encountered so far in the short time I have spent gaming. Thankfully the £50-odd quid spent on the game was not mine.

Each expansion doesn't introduce much, in the ways of new mechanics, its just one supercilious theme after the next. Light humour mockumentery themes being Munchkins strong point. The game was fun, for 5 min.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
You dont have to play this game it playes itself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Not the most in-depth card game out there, but is worth checking out if you have spent any amount of time playing dungeon crawl type RPGs like AD&D... many of the cards reflect very real "munchkin" like behavior.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
A good idea for a game but it can go on for a bit.  Especially annoying if you get whacked when you are close to winning.  FROWN.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The cards and art are funny and punny. The actual gameplay is very drawn-out for the final stretch though. You essentially have to wait for all other players to exhaust their cards for someone to win and take the winning level. There have been games where someone teams up with someone at level 9 to help them defeat their last monster just so the game will finally end.

Maybe okay if you are drinking or want to play a long game [ie: 1-2 hours]. Each additional player you add adds roughly 40-60 minutes to the length of the game so beware.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Funny parodies and wordplays. The game isn't very entertaining, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I got a good item. I was forced to discard it on the next turn. I had a card to get it back from the discard pile. Someone took the card away. I gained a level, but then I lost it somehow. I tried to fight a monster, but another player cursed me and I died. Then we played for another hour.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is a fun little game.  It's entertaining, humorous, and a good parody of Dungeons & Dragons, that you don't have to be a D&D nerd to enjoy.   

Very simple to understand rules.  Cards are hilarious.  There's sort of a gang-up-on-the-leader mentality, but this is a game you play to have fun, rather than "to win" anyway. 

Only downside is that it hasn't had much longevity for me personally.  I've grown increasingly bored with it after a few plays.   Still, it was worth maybe a good half-dozen plays before I grew tired with it. Probably worth a "6" or so, but I don't think I could get into it so much as to buy the million or so expansions. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Rules Version 1.04

Played only a few times so cards remain crisp; includes a Munchkin Dice set (six [6] huge 10-sided dice that can be used to keep track of your Level Number and 14 additional cards), a Level 8 Awful Green Thing promo card, The Official Munchkin Bookmark of Boom and Bust and The Official Munchkin Bites! Bookmark of Powerful Empowerment.

RATING: 5

There are games that do things that Munchkin does, but better.

RATING: 5
Munchkin is about as random as this thoughtful gamer ever wants to get. Charging into battle with nothing more than an overplayed theme (which is what I happen to like most about the game), Munchkin has a barrier for entry that will have most people locking the dungeon door rather than kicking it in.

RATING: 4
Games of Munchkin usually either suffer from runaway leader...or gang up on the leader. The person to win is the one who can either jump to an insurmountable lead, or the last one to reach level 10 after everyone else has used their cards to stop other players. 

The novelity wears off quickly with this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game served its purpose for when I was a more casual card/board gamer who was more into RPGs, collectible card games like MTG, and Table top war games. It is now a dated "old guard" sort of game that I will never play again. It is too simple and never ends. There are now so many expansions that it has collapsed in on itself and will be in the next Niel Degrass Tyson show about black holes. It is probably useful for trying to bridge people who play D&D to other board games or to make certain people hate board games in general. I guess if I were in a relationship with Munchkin, I'd say something like, "its not you. Its me. We have grown apart. You haven't changed, or done anything wrong, I've just grown as a person and no longer share the same interests or friends as you." etc.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
I know, I know, Munchkin.  But really, its a fun way to get family and other non-gamers to the table to have some fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's a stupid, unbalanced, unfair, cheap game that might lead you into a serious argument with your best friends. The rules make no sense, there is (almost) no serious strategy possible. By now, I kind of dislike the author for making way too much money by producing more and more low-fidelity expansions. But then, again, I always look forward to a game of Munchkin with friends like a kid looking forward to meeting Santa (i.e. with lots of excitement and a tiny bit of fear).

RATING: 6
Munchkin is a good little game IF your expectations and needs match what it delivers. I've soured on it over time due to the lack of meaningful choices and arbitrary "take that"-iness, but it's not a bad way to introduce folks to the hobby. Quick, fun art, inexpensive, and easy to teach.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
My biggest problem with this game is that being the 1st person to reach level 8 or 9 has such a huge disadvantage. Every game I've played, everyone spends all their cards in their hand on the first player trying to reach level 10 and by the time the second person comes around, no one has cards left in their hand so the person is usually able to defeat the enemy with no problem. I also hate if someone at level 9 randomly draws a level 1 monster and easily wins the game due to randomness of cards.

RATING: 5
I love this game BUT...

The flow is a bit jarring and the cards are unclear. I catch myself directing each players turn like I'm narrating the game. No matter how often people play they still need to be nudged " no that doesn't go in you backpack" or it's not time to play that yet.

I think with a group of experienced players I could really go for this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Fun though it can be slow and never-ending.  We played it with level 7 as the win-con.  (The rules suggest level 10, I think.)  I would play it occasionally (maybe).

ADDENDUM (12/30/17):  I've played this (and one or two of its variants) a few times since my initial review/reaction.  I don't disagree with it and I'm leaving my original rating (because from my eurogamer perspective it is spot on)...

BUT.  (There's a but.)  BUT... the game is great for kids!  My students enjoy playing it.  The game is horribly random at times and well overstays its welcome, BUT they like it!  So I can't (and won't) discount it and I've even invested in it (y'know, for kids!).

Worth playing with kids.  Because they may like it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This was my gateway game! I fell in love right away, and it has been my favorite game ever since. 

The only reason that is not on my table more often is because we don't have the third player and it's kinda of hard to introduce to non-gamers. We introduced it to friends and family, some loved right away and some lost the interest in the middle of the game. Because of that I would say this is a Medium to Medium-Light weight, definitely not for everyone.

But it will always be my favorite! I guess most people feel that way about their gateway games. :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
One of the first games that I have played.  In this game, it is trying to mimick RPG computer games which players can take on different races and classes of the game.  Players are also required to beat monsters so that they can gain levels to win the game eventually.

Players can protect themselves by equiping themselves with amours, footwear, head gear and weapons so as to fend themselves with more powerful monsters.  Each monsters they beat will not only help themselves to gain levels but also treasures.  Players can asks peers to help them during battles, but peers may also help monsters to defeat you and weaken you during the game.

However players not only meet monsters in the game, they may be caught in some traps which will also weaken them in the course of play.  The first player to reach level 10 will be declared as the winner of the game.

Good points: An easy game to play with.  Players can have a lot of fun helping the monsters to defeat other players.

Bad points: If the initial cards are not useful / helpful in play, players will suffer for quite a bit in the game.  It is also tiring to read the effects of different cards whenever they are drawn into player's hands and players may mis-interpreted the cards effects.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Munchkin and every expansion...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Munchkin is tons of fun with a little more substance than Killer Bunnies. The win condition is to level up to level 10 first by defeating a monster. In many ways, Munchin has all the benefits of KB (humour, fun, etc.) without the lucky carrot factor. However, I do agree that Munchin does have a perchance to have a drawn out endgame that is sometimes painfully long.

As a side note, last night we played an epic 3.5 hour Munchin game where all 5 players fluctuated between levels 8-9 for over 1 hour. We attribute this to the Rat On A Stick card - if we're playing the card correctly, any monster that attacks that is level 8 or lower can be dismissed (i.e. no battle) if the owner of the ROAS discards. Last night, the winning player sunk to level 1 due to the W. Brothers monster (while everyone else kept their level 8-9) and then made a comeback by collecting charity cards and being the first player everyone turned to for help.

NEW! After reviewing the comments on BGG, I've decided to implement the following house rule for Munchkins: when the last card is drawn from the Search The Room deck, the game ends on that turn. I'll try this next time and see if it improves the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This game has a bit of a social stigma around gamers. It is hated because of its popularity and simplicity. 

The game is rather enjoyable when you play it without a predisposition toward disliking it. The mechanics are simple, there is a bit of luck involved, its got a backstabbing setup that adds fun, but it has become a bit of a cash cow.

If you ignore the obvious "steve jackson wants to milk this golden child of a game" greedy production setup, then the game is fun. If you play the game for just the game its a lot of fun.

Have to dock it some points for being repetative though.

With the right group of people this game can be a trip through nostalgia and will surely be enjoyable.

RATING: 7
A parody card game based on RPG concept.  You start with a level 1 character and attempted to reach level 10.  Along the way you kick down doors and run into various monsters and if you are lucky, the other players will help you defeat them with a share of the loot.  Of course they can still screw you up with mod cards to make your monster encounter tougher.  Treasure card are either one shot bonus to combat or permanents.  Taught this to Aaron's cousins in about 15 min.  Need 3 or more to play.

RATING: 7
Is lucky and can drag on at the end, but felt like a variant on Cosmic Encounter (one of my favorite games).  Definitely worth owning if you're looking for a more portable version of CE, and with the plethora of versions out there, there should be one theme which you can get into.

More on the game: The rules are very easy to teach, but the game length can last about 30 minutes to an hour over how long I'd like the game to play around (~1 hour, meaning the game usually takes 90-120 minutes).

RATING: 1
The biggest problem Munchkin has apart from the terrible artwork and awful jokes is a game that feels as though it should only take 10 or 20 minutes can take hours to play. The game drags on for what seems an eternity and that much time spent with the 'humour' and 'artwork' is demoralising. I feel stupider after playing it and that's not a good sign.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
While this game is highly based on luck, I know of few other games that can get cause the level of laughter and entertainment as Munchkin. I would suggest this game should be played with a minimum of 5 players (although you will need to own at least one expansion for this to work out well) as the lower the number of players, the more personal people seem to take curses etc. With larger numbers, more people get cursed and Wandering Monstered and thus your players see it more as part of the ethos of the game and not a personal attack on them.

RATING: N/A
Munchkin's artwork is hilarious, and I love a good backstabbing game full of twists and over-the-top silliness, so I was enthralled when I first came across this game. However, once the novelty of the cards wears off, gameplay isn't all that inspiring. 

Most of our games ended up very unbalanced. In all fairness, I have mostly played Munchkin with two players; so, since it's not supposed to be a 2-player game, I decided not to rate it. But I can't imagine that it would play much different with 3 or 4.

RATING: 3
Humor can only carry you along so far before it drones on too long.  The open-ended-ness of this game is what kills it.  It needed to be short and sweet.  Kick the humor in and keep the game play on the same level as the jokes.  But the game goes on longer than the jokes can hold up.  In the end it just tires you out and you'll find yourself wondering what a game of Munchkin: The Suicides would play like.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
At some point, the game just becomes a ridiculous "Take That!" game, where whoever is in first when everyone else has used up all of their cards, wins. This makes the game feel like a random mess most of the time. Generally, the leader in the beginning game is the loser in the end game. With the right group, this game can be great, but otherwise avoid. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.3
Play it with friends, and beer, and a sense of humor. This is just not the sort of game that will win accolades based on its mechanics alone, but a sort of communal good time, so I'm not surprised it receives a lot of vitriol from the board gaming community. I find it fun to mix and match the various genres/sets and come up with some truly random and bizarre 'narrative', makes it all the more hilarious, but this is really the only mindset to approach Munchkin with if you want to enjoy it and not tear it apart.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Fun and light at 30 minutes.  If a standard game took that long, it'd be higher rated for me.  However, even the base game takes more like an hour or more.  Still, the base game is better than most alternatives for some family scenarios where something like hearts is too heavy.  (that is more a complement to hearts than a dig at munchkin).

The base game does have some thought and decision making, that does in fact matter, even if diluted by chance, so there is some decent game here.

The epic version is horrible for me, although I only played it once and got completely crushed by a sequence of bad luck.  Sitting around while 5 other players do 'epic' turns, and you get a quick normal pointless turn, and have no leverage to be involved in anything but your own turn, for another 90 minutes is quite painful.

Basically, epic takes a decent light and almost quick game and totally breaks it.  Completely awful.

RATING: 6
A fun experience of getting your friends killed, as you try to level up to 10, with some nice amusing cartoony art.

I feel the most fun is just seeing the cool art of a monster, and hearing the amusing things it does if it kills you.

However, the gameplay has too much 'take-that', in that players have so much ability to stop a player from winning, the game can drag on FOREVER, overstaying its welcome by a long shot.

RATING: 7
Munchkin is a fun game, but since it is so depending on your card draws, you can be pretty bored and not a part of the game. If there could be a bank or vendor system for someone who keeps getting shafted to get a leg up when the rest of the players are in their "late game" phases, then it could help balance things out. Still, it's fun to stab your buddies and kill the monsters, and the zany cards, art, and descriptions are a lot of fun too.

RATING: 7

Everyone still likes it, understanding that it's just a fun time waster more than anything. Personally, I see it as a stealth RPG, where the cards are just props for the characters to play with, since the whole point is to act like a moron. It's a fun game with the right understanding.

RATING: 7
Modified game start with character drafting phase with basic equipment and ability to re-roll at a cost. Door deck deadlier with weight twoards curse, monster buffs, higher level monsters. RATING: 5
I wanted to fall in love with this game, I really do - received it as a birthday present. However, the game is too much luck-dependent to even have any strategy to it. Gameplay is too swingy, too random and it reallyyyyyyyyyy drags. This is the only game that I would wish it to end faster even if I lose in the process. And this game really encourages the players to gang-up on the leader, which ended up dragging the game even longer.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
This isn't a game, it's torture. A pure money machine for Steve Jackson with no redeeming quality in my opinion. It's purely a "take that" game which rewards you for cheating. You actually can buy addition items to give you personal advantages in the game. Why learn how to get better at a game? You can just use a card from an "official" pay phone app. Or maybe instead you just bought a bookmark that gives you an added bonus. Or a Tee shirt that if you flash during the game gives you an advantage. If you padded Steve Jackson's wallet enough then you get a major boost over people that didn't drink the kool-aid.

If you own this "game" and actively push your friends to play, then they can't be blamed when they stab you... wait, let's be serious, if you own this "game" and actively push people to play it then you don't have any friends.

Why does this game have a bazillion re-themes but I can't buy Ogre Pocket off the shelf at my local shop? Sometimes the world makes me cry. This is one of those times.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's fun and interesting, but random, and players always target the player who's about to win, to such a degree that being ahead is a disadvantage. Haven't found a way to fix this issue.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Played with the epic rules for a while, but realized that it was silly (and long) enough without them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I played a lot of munchkin in college. I mean a lot. Possibly more than any other game except for euchre. Its easy to teach and the cards are humorous. Ultimately it's just a take that game where you equip cards and use cards against monsters and possibly your opponents. The main issue with this game is twofold. One, the game is very lucky. If you start out with a lot of good stuff, you will likely win, unless everyone successfully gangs up on you, which leads to the second main issue. Almost every game is won by the second person attempting to get to the last level needed to win. Usually everyone must gang up on the first person to attempt to get to lvl 10, and usually they don't have enough for the second guy. In my experience this happens 9/10 games. Different versions can still be fun, but you honestly can't take the game seriously at all, or you're gonna have a bad time. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
Such garbage! 

The mass text on all the cards lead this to being WAY slower and WAY longer than it needed to be. 

Luck can completely ruin someone elses night because there's a fair chance that they'll get nothing at all to help them defeat monsters, and then they may continue to draw nothing useful while everyone else around them raises in level.

The 'humor' in the game isn't funny enough to warrant the super bad art style.

Hurting others just feels like your prolonging the game unless your tied for the lead, since it didn't seem like it was easy to catchup if your behind. This makes my favored 'create all the chaos' method of gameplay not too great in this game

RATING: 2
No matter how hard you try to like it, Munchkin is still one of the most annoying games I’ve ever played: it looks like a harmless filler but then it requires way too much time and effort before it comes to an end, which makes it the opposite of a filler. It isn’t funny either, as the jokes about bad roleplaying habits can be funny so many times only, even to a veteran roleplayer.

All in all the game boils down to a «gain a level, lose a level» turnover until all players but one (the winner-to-be) have had enough of it and do their best to cut it short.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The king of the take that card game genre.  You'll find more vocal haters for this game than practically any other.  Somebody out there loves it because it's one of the most popular, best selling card games in the hobby.  Personally, if played with friends it makes for a dumb way to waste an hour.  It's best with drinks and if it's not taken seriously at all.  The bash the leader endgame can be brutal...but I've rarely seen it cause a game last much longer than an hour.  When played with lots of interaction, wheeling and dealing this CAN be a fun game. It doesn't take much to ruin the experience though. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
As a game: 4. As beer and pretzels fun with certain groups: 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Great casual game for Tabletop RPG or Fantasy genre lovers (and on through the various expansion/variations - which is up to 8 or 9 in the core set alone).

Pretty much a very mildly cooperative but completely screw your neighbor style card game.  Loads of expansions and even some of the variations can be combined.

You are an adventurer that is looking for glory (reaching level 10 before anyone else) by defeating monsters and collecting loot, however part of the game play is messing with (or sometimes helping) the other players when they are attempting to defeat those monsters or collect that loot.

Pretty easy game to learn.  Other than the basic rules it's pretty much one of those "Just do what the card says" type games that shouldn't require a lot of explanation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fast paced and silly.... hack and slash.... kill your friend and take his stuff. Very funny

RATING: 6
When judged as "just another game", Munchkin obviously falls flat. It takes far too long for such a random game, it is mainly bash-the-leader and the winner is the one who tries last to get to level 10 after all the good cards of his opponents have already been exhausted. Now, introduce a home rule where you have to drink a shot for every time you lose a level, invite a couple of people over who like fantasy and get the jokes, and it's going to be a blast.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
First, I am a big fan of fantasy/RPG/D&D-type games. I thought I would like this game. I considered buying it for a year or so before I finally broke down and bought it (the price was pretty steep).

Me, my wife, and another couple played this game. My wife and I ended up HATING it (even though I won), but my friends liked it. So it wasn't a total loss, I sold it to them, recooping most of the money I spent on it. I have absolutely no desire to play this game ever again.

The Good:
1. Um, the cards were mildly entertaining the FIRST time you read them.

The Bad:
1. WAY too expensive for what you get.
2. Even though this is a simple game, there are a whole slew of ambiguities in determining how different cards work together.
3. Artwork is ugly.
4. No replay value (not that there is much FIRST play value).
5. BORING.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very popular game with some funny cards.  Mechanics are 'meh' to me.  It's very popular and easy to get and learn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It starts off well, the jokes are amusing...the first time. Then the games goes on...and on until the theme bleeds off. You're left with a game of simply adding one, subtracting one, etc. in ever taller stacks of cards and the person who can angle socially to play the last card wins. The basic strategies are obvious and the resolution after a long session of arithmetic could simply hinge on a flipped coin. Aspects of this game are fun but they're much better represented in more viable games. Your group might get a few laughs out of a few games if you play with no more than three players, but if you want to pass the time with cards in your hand, Citadels is a better choice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not a brilliant game, but really great at the niche it serves: sort of low-mental-effort quick party game for gamers.

It's in that category with Fluxx and Chez Geek. I'm a fan of the Steve Jackson style quirky sense of humor, so I don't mind this one too much.

All these games have essentially the same problem, they don't really force an ending in a specific amount of time, so games have really random play lengths, sometimes erring on too long for such lightweight filler-between-two-serious-games games.

After you get all the jokes, not much replayability either.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Meh. Never take it seriously and you'll do okay...

RATING: 5
Welllllllll...it's not a BAD game. The outcome and overall play style is the EXACT same EVERY time. Once you realize that most likely everyone is going to reach level nine and then wait around 'til someone can level up because everyone used all of their "gotcha" cards, it just loses it's appeal. I'm also not a fan of introducing new gamers to something so simplistic because it can create a false impression of what a game should or can be.

RATING: 7.1
Lots of fun.  So far everyone who has played has enjoyed it a lot.  Initially rated the game a bit low because of the weak rule explanation, but now that we are more comfortable and have modified things to our understanding of the rules, I have upped my rating.  Much of the rating is for the fun factor.  Game play at times is actually kinda tedious.  I do like that in most games the scores are pretty close, mostly a result of the leader being ganged up on the others. many people give this game a low rating but they are wrong.  If the people playing aren't into the fun of it, then it will be a grind to play.  That is not the games fault, it is the players fault.  
We play with the 2 expansions each time and it works great.

RATING: 4
Rating of 4 is based on a handful of plays.  Would play again if asked, but this really doesn't grab me -- so many other, better games out there.

Most recent play included several new players, two of whom dropped out before everyone had taken a turn.  Between rules confusion and perceived (or real?) rules complexity (What cards can I keep? Which ones can I play, and when?), it was too much for them.  The rest of us continued to play for a few rounds.  One player was stuck at level 1, with one card in play and none in his hand, while others had a lot of cards in play and were a few levels higher.  The game ended when a couple of us piled onto an attack, which was deflected to me.  I was defeated and played "Rocks Fall", which killed us all.  That was enough for all but two in the group,  and they realized we would all be happier playing something else.

RATING: 2.5
One of the first non-standard games I've played, and at the time it was one of my favorites. Lots of laughs to be had with the puns and humor. Loose rules that lead to a lot of arguing and debating among friends.

Generally this game comes down to sheer luck. Second place almost always comes out on top... 

Now it is one of my least favorite games. All luck, no skill. Clunky rules. No difficult decisions. It's good for a few laughs, but it loses its appeal very quickly. I'll probably never play this game again.

RATING: N/A
Le mécanisme de jeu de Munchkin se veut volontairement une traduction la plus fidele possible d'une exploration de donjon basique. C'est un dungeon crawler... sans le donjon. Le matériel de jeu est simple : une pile de cartes Donjon, une autre Trésor. Au début du jeu, chaque joueur tire 2 cartes Donjon et 2 Trésor, et créer son personnage niveau 1(en posant devant lui les éventuels cartes Race, Classe, Objet Magique et Pouvoirs en tout genre).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In the beginning we had a ton of fun with this. This little card game can be epic! (when in the right mood with the right people.) The cards are funny and the rules are silly and that makes the perfect environment for mean and crazy play.

After a while not only the cards but also the backstabbing scenarios become well known and then the replay value is lost. Then it feels like the game drags on much too long, especially with high player counts.

It's necessary that everybody remembers to keep the good cards for the right moment, to prevent someone reaching level 10, otherwise it's pretty random who's winning. Basically the only skill in the game is to hold back on the good cards longer than anybody else, pretending not to have any, and then to find the right moment to reach for level 10, when the others have no good cards left.

If nobody draws any cards to interact or if they play them too early, the game can be extremely boring.

# of players: [bgcolor=#00CC00] 3 [b]4[/b][/bgcolor][bgcolor=#99FFFF] 5 6[/bgcolor]

RATING: 5

When I trialled it with my friends, the game went over well. It's a good game, you just have to find the group that makes it one. It's too long, and it drags until everyone's out of cards. Sure, it's fun, but that fun happens up until level 5, then it just gets tedious.

RATING: 3
It's boring to hate on Munchkin.  It's a bad game for all the reasons everyone knows.  It takes too long, there are no interesting decision, every game has the same arc, kingmaking is ubiquitous.

But in it's defense, I played 100s of games in college and I really loved it!  I think I still have the base game and a few expansions.  I haven't played it in 8 years, but it's no good to pretend that I never liked it.

For young guys who just want to laugh about silly fantasy jokes and fool around while messing up each others' game, it's a fine experience.  Not a "good boardgame" and I won't give it a good rating, but it certainly has its demographic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Cosmic Encounter is one of my favourite games, Munchkin borrows mechanics from Cosmic and puts a twist on it. Another great game with take that, negotiation, betrayal, teamwork and backstabbing. I really like this game. My favourite Munchkin memory: In typical family gathering fashion, the boys went downstairs to play some Munchkin at 9:00pm in my grandparents tiny office void of windows to the outside world. Later that night after several games and not a clock in sight, we all guessed what time it must be and the closest would get to move up a level for free. My uncle came back downstairs from checking the clock and though I was closest with my guess of 3:30am, I was still way off as it was 6:45am and the sun was up! Needless to say we ended the game immediately and dispersed to our appointed sleeping chambers. I tried to crawl into bed with my wife without waking her up but was quickly greeted with, "ARE YOU KIDDING ME?!!” :) Good Times.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is drastically better with only the base set or adding one or two expansions.  It gets very unwieldy the more you add to it, with constant pulling of less-than-useful cards, and difficulty making things work together properly.  If you pick up several expansions, I reccommend a sorting to choose which you use at different times, to avoid diluting the basic essence of the game.

I never thought I would find a game I dislike worse than [thing=3699]Killer Bunnies[/thing] (let me remind you that Killer Bunnies is a game in which the winner is determined [i]randomly![/i]), but all I could think during this excruciating experience is, "What did I ever do to [i]you[/i]?" This is, without question, my new most hated "game."

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is light and mostly fun entertainment, and can be played 1) with non-gamers, 2) with children (or the elderly), and 3) after one has had a few drinks and does not wish to bend his mind too much.

For that reason, it is difficult to fully understand the unvarnished hatred for this game by many users at this site.   It isn't supposed to be some deep, mentally engaging brain burner.  It was designed to be:  a) kind of stupid, and b) a chop-down-the-leader type of game.  It succeeds at those, I think.

That being said, however, we do not play this any more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Quirky and fun, but with silly mechanics and almost no structure. The point of Munchkin isn't to be a good "game" but to be whacky and outrageous, and in that regard it usually succeeds. A great game, worthy of praise, but one that is definitely overrated (But only because it's such a huge sensation!).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This is basically Progress Quest: The Card Game. 

Which is to say, it's a parody of people who play D & D (and its ilk) in an almost hypnotically uninteresting way by simulating a D & D game with all except the almost hypnotically uninteresting elements removed. I make it a point of pride to never intentionally throw a game just because I'm bored (the theory being that presumably someone at the table is having fun), but I ended up winning because someone threw the game to me. This is probably not a hopeful sign, nor is the fact that I was saying things like "KILL IT WITH FIRE" after the game passed the 60 minute mark. Cut the average playtime at least in half, you may have a decent-but-still-not-appealing-to-me lil' filler. As is, please note that Progress Quest can be downloaded on all major OSes. For free. Munchkin costs 25 bones.

Avoids being a one just because it contains recognizable game-like elements.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game seems friendly until the end, when all bets are off. You need help to progress levels, but no one will assist in that last level, so you have to be able to beat the final monster(s), plus the extras opponents throw at you, by yourself. Might be fun with 4 or less people, I have only played it with larger groups.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
#25

Game is filled with bargaining, pleading, begging, betrayal and screwage. The expansion packs make the game more fun, especially the expansion that rewards for helping other players rather than trying to screw them all the time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is our go-to party game and probably the most played game in our collection. It's funny, it's fun, it's really easy to teach to people and appeals to a wide range of our friends from complete non-gamers to hardcore gamers. We have purchased expansions to twist the game more to our liking (more modifier cards are a must to make it more munchkiny). Games can take anywhere from 30 to 90 minutes depending how much time the group spends mucking around sledging each other.

This is the first "new" board game we bought. Thanks TableTop.

I dislike that your belt has endless capacity - I like the rule from Munchkin Quest that lets you have as many one-shot items on your belt as you like but only 2 equip-able items. It's possible to speed up or slow down the game by increasing or decreasing the amount of cards you get at the start of the game.

I can understand that some people don't like this game - There is a lot of luck, players can just decide to gang up on one particular person and there isn't much they can do about it, it's possible to be a kingmaker and it's possible to have no interest in winning at all and just ruin other peoples battles. There's also a problem with people just saving their cards to deal with the first player who looks like they are going to win instead of interacting with each other the whole way through.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
My opinon fluctuates with this game. The base set is amusing for awhile, however, I really don't think it would hold up to regular play without sinking money into the various expansions. That said, it's easy for non-gamers to play, and good fun with beers. I also purchased the Munchkin brand xp wheels since I was hoping to not deal with counters. I'd rather play Talisman and it's various expansions, despite it's fiddly, random nature and bits.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I played this game so much in college it might be my most played of all my board games, with Catan as a close second. I've since moved on to bigger and better things, but this game gave me a heck of a lot of bang for my buck.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Good game to play in a group as it is fairly easy to learn. Strategy wise I have learned (across the different versions) that the first player to make it to level 9 rarely wins. When they have to fight that last monster to win the game the others players will pull out everything to prevent it. Last game I played (Munchkin Fu) I was level 9, had 30 strength (and plently of pump ups) vs a level 1 monster and still managed to lose due to the others throwing everything they had at me. The next player to reach Level 9 won easily as all the nasty cards had been burned. So bit of advice - be strategic about when you hit Level 9.

RATING: 3
Hát ez nem nyert... első olyan játék, amit -egyelőre- megbántam, hogy elkészítettem házilag. Bár nagyon sokat dolgoztam vele, a társaságnak nem jött be. Nekem egy fokkal jobban tetszett, mint nekik - jobban kedvelem az ilyen fárasztó poénokat és ha fordítás közben nem tetszett volna, úgyis abbahagyom - de sajnos van egy olyan érzésem, hogy ritkán fog előkerülni...

Még egy megjegyzés: Leginkább a gond azzal van, hogy minden kártyán más utasítás van, azt végig kell olvasni, "elemezni", eldönteni mit mikor játszok ki, stb. Ez viszont lelassítja a játékot. Márpedig egy játék akkor lesz igazán vicces, ha pörgős!

Update: négy fővel is kipróbáltuk. Okés, játszható és nem rossz játék, de nem az én világom. Szeretem az átlátható, világos szabályokat és szerintem ha egy játék ennyire engedi, hogy tisztázatlan dolgok történjenek, és engedi vitázni a társaságot, akkor elrontja a játék lényegét. Mi nagyon barátságosan játszottunk, nem vitáztunk meg ilyesmi, de még itt is előjöttek nagyon vitás dolgok. És ezekkel csak az idő fogyott, meg a kedv... Szóval többet inkább NEM.

5-6 éve készítettem házilag a játékot. Én fordítottam le a lapokat magyar nyelvűre (ennek oka, hogy az eredeti angol nyelvű kártyák és a magyar kiadás között rengeteg félrefordítást találtam), nyomtattam, vágtam, ragasztottam, saját dobozzal rendelkezik. Ezért sem adtam el, eddig. De értelmetlen, hogy a szekrény leghátsó részén porosodjon.

Ár: 3.500 Forint
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Like most Steve Jackson games, Munchkin isn't a game.  It's a medium for Jackson's twisted humor.  By all means, read the cards and laugh ... but the game play is just painfully awful.

Specifically: I dislike that everyone's incentive at the table (if you're not the leader) is to prolong the game. I could have more fun with the munchkin system if it worked toward an ending and wrapped up in that 30 minute area ... but I've sat through too many painful episodes that went on for hours ...

RATING: 7
Munchkina poznałam na imprezie u znajomych, początkowo gra była bardzo chaotyczna, wiele rzeczy wychodzi dopiero w praniu przy wykładaniu kart, kiedy wydaje się, że koniec rozgrywki jest już blisko, nagle wszyscy rzucają faworytowi kłody pod nogi i jazda zaczyna się od nowa. Rozgrywka może trwać nawet kilka godzin (never ending story), w zależności od liczby osób, ułożenia kart i determinacji graczy. To pewnie dlatego Munchkina albo się kocha albo nienawidzi. Tutaj nici z Twoich strategii i planów, gra totalnie zaskakuje, śmieszne obrazki i komiczne tytuły kart z ich opisami powodują rozbawienie, brawa dla kreatywności tłumacza. Ogrom negatywnej interakcji.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Post-Wheaton effect buy.
Eh...a relic of times gone past. I mean, it was...OK. I kinda appreciate the humour as it's self depreciating and kinda appropriate for the game. 

As a randomised 'take that' encounter engine, it suceeds insomuch that you can suceed, buff youself, get in the way of other players and have a good time with your friends being jerks to each other.  In the same vein, there is equal possibility of having a fast game where you zoom to victory without being stopped or squander at level 1 because the draws prevent you from fighting monsters or getting enough stuff to beat them. 

Maybe I'm just a hipster. It was fine. I can play this, and I understand why people can enjoy this. Though (like any patron of the fast flowing 'net) I'd rather play the stuff that is new.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Good gateway game, albeit a bit silly. Almost every game I have played suffers from the same problem, where one player gets ahead and then everyone attacks him to knock him back to level 0. Then one lucky person takes advantage of everyone else having used their weapons/etc and ends up winning. But it can still be a decent social game, especially for lighter gamers.

Plays
2012 - 1
2014 - 1

RATING: 1
I consider this to be one of the biggest boardgaming failures. It has a terrible endgame that lasts forever in which players constantly stop one another from winning without doing anything to progress their own position. You would have to pay me a fair amount to make me sit down to play a game of this, and I would feel no compulsion to avoid making this miserable game even worse.

RATING: 6
[b]Warehouse23 - Christmas 2013[/b] 
I love the humor in this game.  The only downside is with the luck of the draw.  Some game plays the same person gets cursed almost every turn.  Other game plays a player will get hardly any bonuses.  To me that all part of the game play and replay-ability.  Most importantly my kids love playing this game with me.

RATING: 7
All the reasons everyone rags on Munchkin are all the reasons my family loves it:
-It's random--my 10 year old step son, while happy to play heavy games, has a hard time developing winning long-term strategies. He likes this game because "I can win that one"
-It's silly/not serious--Perfect! Right up our alley. We prefer to describe it as comical and light
-It can lead to "take that" gameplay--It's would argue it's encouraged. We enjoy that mechanic and aren't sore losers...so...TAKE THAT!

I don't know, we enjoy it. Enough said
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Enjoyable light hearted fantasy game, but often maligned because most games are very samey when it comes to mechanics and playstyles, and I have to concur. There are a lot of cards to screw with the leader or various other players, often resulting in the game winner being placed in a kingmaker situation or everyone else simply running out of attack cards at the wrong time. Still, it is quite enjoyable just in smaller spurts. The expansions add a lot of the same, but breathe new life with more funny but not a lot of mechanics. A bit light and casual, but I wouldn't pass up a play.

RATING: 6
When I first played Munchkin, I enjoyed it quite a bit. The learning curve was shallow and design was silly and accessible.

As I've gone on to play more games, I've found that Munchkin has ended up in the dust behind games that do what it does better. Also, sorry to say, the jokes do sort of lose their charm after a couple of plays - we get it, nerd stuff is funny.

I don't think anyone is going to come away from Munchkin having had a really terrible time, but there's better games out there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The dungeon-crawling card game that started them all, Munchkin is an adorable card game where you try to defeat monsters and go up in levels until you kill one final monster and reach level ten. Illustrated by the visual genius of John Kovalic, the artist behind the newspaper comic strip Dork Tower, the cards are wonderful to look at and the gameplay is just top notch. I would love to get the many expansions for this game but even the base game is fun. Good game to play before a campaign session of D&D or any other tabletop RPG you play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For a game that hasn't been redesigned for its rerelease other than the addition of a board, I'm a little frustrated.  They should just price it $30 instead of $20 and include the expansions Munchkin 2 Unnatural Axe and  Munchkin 3 Clerical Errors.  As it stands, I feel cheated every time I take the lid off the base game box to see the tiny stack of cards dwarfed by the gigantic box they're inside.  But instead they nickel and dime us.  Argh.  Anyway, the game itself is a light and fun dungeon crawler parody that I love playing as a backup with groups that can't handle a more complex game.  The board, although small and incredibly simple improves the experience tenfold while still sticking to the original formula everyone loves.  Munchkin quest is also fun, but it's no longer as simple as convenient.  And let's face it, that's the only reason I reach for this over more complex games.  Groups that want something simple and fun.  Not everyone is on board for a 5 hour Arkham Horror or Twilight Struggle session and this is sure to keep that crowd happy.  This and Lords of Waterdeep are my go-to simple games.  And they are both very fun and very easy to teach.  Get the expansions for replayability and help Steve Jackson buy another house.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
2 to 6 players. Hilarious cards and funny game play. It's a game that doesn't take itself seriously and I've found it to be pretty fun. Because of the constant involvement of everyone trying to screw everyone else games can end up taking a long time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I do love the illustrations and some cards are hilarious. It's hit or miss for sure, but the style and art is maybe the best thing munchkin has to offer.

While the game is really simple, the rules are often not very clear and a match can take very long because of high inbalance and players targeting the highest-leveled player.

Make house rules for when the game ends and it's much better! Some expandions (like the dungeons or Munchkinomicon) can make it even quicker.

RATING: 2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I personally really like this game, but it's hit or miss for my friends.  It's simple enough to teach the basics, but there are always so many detail questions that come up, and I had struggled to find the answer when needed. I feel that the rulebook could have been a bit better.  Basic concept - each player is a simple human to begin, and as you "adventure" and search different rooms of the "dungeon" (it's a card game, so this is all in concept), you fight monsters, and gain treasures, and level up your "character" along the way.  The final goal is to reach level 10 by defeating a monster.  A frustration I have is the amount that luck comes in to play as far as being able to affect other players combat to "win" the game.  But, all in all, it's a fun enough game in my opinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
damned if i could get my head around this.  totaly head fucked!!! sheesh..

RATING: 5

WHatever strategy you have can be thwarted by the other players if they have the right cards.  After a few plays through the jokes can get old and the game looses some appeal, but that's what the expansions are for!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Currently I just own the original version of Munchkin without any upgrades.  I have read a few reviews of this that say it isn't funny if you have never played a fantasy RPG, especially D&D.  This isn't true, my partner, who has never touched an RPG in her life chuckled plenty but there are jokes in here that will only be got by old D&D afficianados.  The magic missile for instance, the staple of the 1st level wizard in D&D, is represented here but drawn as one of the least aerodynamic ICBMs ever.

The game itself is quite playable and the rules can be picked up  easily enough by playing the first game "open".  That way the options of play become apparent to all.  There are one or two small ambiguities in the rules but these are, on the whole, addressed by the FAQ section at the Steve Jackson Game's Website.

Play it and enjoy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Very entertaining game, with some fun and innovative mechanics. We often use this when we've little time left, but still want to try something that doesn't take ages (of civilization) to set up. 

Taken for what it is, a short and fun game, meant to be played on expense of whomever you can gang up on, it's a very nice game.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This was one of my 'gateway' games into the hobby. Played it in college with my roommates a few times and went out to buy a heap of expansions. Played a few more times with said expansions and then the game just faded from our favor.

Likes:
I like the sheer variety of cards the game comes with, the different classes/races/etc that promote different playstyles and such. The humor is a bit hit-or-miss, but I got a chuckle out of a few card names. 

Dislikes:
Munchkin has a huge pile-on-the-leader problem. Typically whoever is in second place as some approaches level 10 will get the victory as everyone dumps their bad cards on the leader to try to kill them. This was dog-pile was fun the first few times, but soured quickly.

Additionally, Munchkin has this concept of 'munchkinness' which basically boils down to be as big of a asshole as possible. This is a take-that style game, so that would normally be fine. But the game goes out of it's way to promote douchebaggery, such as wearing official merchandise gives you stat boosts and cheating is okay if you aren't caught. This concept just grated on me as we played more games and one particular roommate began taking 'munchkiness' a bit too far.

The game will always have some nostalgia value as one of my first forays into modern boardgames, but its time on my table is over.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

FUN, LIGHT ABSTRACT DUNGEON CARD GAME.

RATING: 7
I have only played Munchkin twice, and each time I loved playing.  Why, then, have I only played twice?  Well, this game is friendship-bane.  There are so many things you can do in this game to just relentlessly screw over the other people you are playing with.  It gets to a point where you get so into messing with other players that you forget to try to win the game.  I stretched one game out to almost two hours by continuously preventing anyone from winning.  I wasn't even trying to win by the end of it, I just wanted to see how many people I could provoke.

I lost two friends that night.

The next game I lost one more.  Point being, if you are Lawful Evil and play this game you will lose a friend.  If you are Chaotic Evil and play this game, you will lose a few.  However, if you are that rare Chaotic Neutral who just likes to see what happens when you pour the gasoline on your own funeral pyre, you may just lose them all.

RATING: 2
I don't want to hate on this game too much - there are plenty of other comments for that. The art is cute, and at times even clever, but every game I've played follows the same progression: everything is fine up until someone gets close to winning, then it's "they're winning, get 'em!" and everyone piles on the leader knocking them down a bit. Then someone else gets close to winning, and it's "get 'em" all over again. This continues until the sun expands to engulf the earth and we all expire as a species ... deep breath ... (calm, calm). Anyhow, if this were a 30 minute game, I'd love it, but as it stands it's so f-ing long that it actually reduces the fun-level of the entire universe by a measurable amount (calm ... calm ... you got rid of the game and don't ever have to play it again ... peace)

RATING: 2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Munchkin still gets played a bit when friends who are afraid of my Euros come over. It's still a fine game, and when played infrequently, the jokes stay pleasantly fresh. It's just that I own two dozen higher-rated games and am unlikely to play it under other circumstances.

It's worth noting, though, that original Munchkin, without expansions, can be a brutal, tactical, sneaky battle, especially when played by overcompetitive folks. With one expansion, I feel this reaches a comfortable compromise; with more, it waters down the game and turns it into a card lottery.

The main flaws with Munchkin are that it takes a bit too long, and almost always leaves 1-2 players card-poor (due to drawing high-level enemies their first few turns).  I need to try a game with a draft of starting equipment/class/races, maybe beginning at level 3 to compensate (and shorten the game)  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
The illustrations are great, and the jokes are pretty funny the first time you see them. But that's only justification enough to look through a copy of the game that some other sap shelled out money for.

The game is completely random, without any real strategy. Its leveling system helps the rich get richer, but not fast enough to end the game until long after the jokes have completely lost their luster. By the time one player has reached level 5, you can be virtually certain he will get to level 10 first and win -- but it's going to take a long while for that to happen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Blech!  Keep away from me you little ...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Most people hate this game, I rather like it. It was one of my first non-Catan/Monolpoly/Clue/etc... games I played and I loved it. More importantly it allowed me to find more friends who liked it, and helped push me down this rabbit hole. Back to the game itself, it's hella random who wins. Constant backstabbing, the endgame is everyone ganging up on whomever's turn it is until the group is out of resources to stop someone, so a real crapshoot.

RATING: 8
Good game, even with only two players. The base rules are pretty straight forward, though unclear card wording may cause some disputes/discussions/research which will slow down gameplay. Official Munchkin items (shirts, dice, iOS app, etc) all have special rules which can change the gameplay experience for better or worse. The themed sets add variety without changing many rules.

RATING: 8
I think Munchkin is a great game, BUT its not serious AT ALL, and if you go into the game wanting something serious and challenging, then you are going to be disappointed.  HOWEVER, if you want a zany game where you get to screw over your friends and kill ridiculous monsters, armed with even more ridiculous equipment, then this is the game for you.  Like many other games, this game is largely based on luck, so if you draw badly, the game can seem nearly impossible, but if you draw well, then you can coast to victory.

RATING: 2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
The game itself is cheeky, cute, and childish in a somewhat fun way.  It would make for a fun 10-15 minute party game.  But a typical game of Munchkin drags out to 45 minutes to an hour, under the pretense that it's a strategic exercise, when in fact players can gang up on each other at their whims and knock each other down arbitrarily.  

Munchkin is trying not to take itself seriously, but then lasts long enough that it should.  This makes it a bad party game (too long) AND a bad strategy game (too whimsical).  And that's not a good place to be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Talk about diminishing marginal utility.  For those of you weren't econ majors, diminishing marginal utility is the minimizing of enjoyment with each successive action.  Example.  Butterfingers.  Taste great with the first bite, start feeling sticky teeth with second bite, feel like barfing after wolfing down a movie theater sized serving.  Alas, I must compare the classic game of Munchkin to that Bart Simpson staple confection.  After my first playing at the san diego comic-con, where a grizzled, overweight, under-bathed man whipped out a severely wrinkled, kids-sized Munchkin shirt to start the game and said in Simpson's Comic Guy voice "I can attempt to put it on, but it won't be pretty." I would have rated this game an instant 10.  Indeed I bought the game at the convention and picked up the subsequent expansions.  Sadly, with time, the magic of that comic-con moment has slowly dwindled away and has left me with naught but fond memories of my 1st spiked cod piece.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Good for time killing. I prefer it from 4 to 6 players

RATING: 5
We really gave this game a chance. Played it many many times but possibly because of the nature of our game group it just got worse the more we played it mostly because the unclear rules regarding some of the combinations of cards. Our games started to last 2-3 hours and involved so much arguing about rules (which is something that normally lessens the more you play, but here there is always something new to argue about). 

Finally decided that it's not worth the hassle anymore. I do however think that in other groups this could play well. Maybe with people who don't care too much about the rules and can easily implement house rules. I know other groups who say that a game of munchkin lasts about 30 minutes - I have no idea how they do it :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I find this to be an extremely unfun game. It devolves into everyone screwing over a person trying to get that last level. The game only ends once everyone has no ability to prevent a player from making a last kill. This is worse than just king-making. The game encourages repeatedly dog-piling the leading player. 

I give the game credit for the humorous feel. The art, card names and most mechanics all play to the goofy D&D parody. Sadly this game will always be taken to seriously because it is a game about being a Munchkin, which goes completely counter to the goofy appearance.

RATING: 5

Definitely play this game at some point to experience the hilarious cards... but in hindsight I rather would have played some one else's copy and not own it myself as it mostly just sits on my shelf.  I whip it out only when people specifically want to try it and have an ok time with it.  Not bad but just never a game I want to play anymore.

RATING: 5.5
My kids love this game. I think it's decent. It's definitely not one of the best games that we own. It's never on the top of my list of things I want to play. However, when I do play it with them, it's always good for a few laughs with the silliness and backstabbing. If I were rating it for just myself, I'd rate it lower, but I think it has a lot of appeal for people who like "Take That" play and fart jokes. After they played it a few times, it really hasn't come out again, much to my relief.

RATING: 3
I loved this game 10 years ago. I didn't know any better.

But upon repeat plays the game plays itself since the best moves are pretty obvious. The humor of the game is very clever but not enough to keep you coming back again and again. Also the combination of a high luck factor, take that game play, and king making is a big negative for me. 

One of the cornerstones of the game is arguing over how the rules apply to specific cards and actions. This too is amusing at first but gets tiresome over time.

*Update: Gave my copy to a friend who actually likes this game.

RATING: 7

My friends and I enjoy it so much I've bought several expansions (both for fantasy Munchkin, + Star Munchkin, etc.). You can't take it too seriously.  It's not about winning, it's about having fun sticking it to the other players and have them stick it to you  There are a lot of ways this can happen and I always enjoy seeing how it's going to happen next.

RATING: 5
(As of [b]?[/b] plays) I used to be enamoured of the Munchkin series, which was partially responsible for bringing me to BGG, but it is certainly a game where familiarity can breed contempt. The humour is great, the artwork is perfect, and the concept of reducing the role-playing experience to its shallowest component elements is fun. The fatal flaw is the directionless randomness and the tortuously prolonged time it takes to finish a game.

[b]5 year verdict:[/b] Munchkin was one of the first non-traditional games I bought, and I played a lot of it early on, but I have definitely moved on.

RATING: 6
Munchkin is a cheesy game that offers a few smiles to those with an affection for fantasy roleplaying. Distilling the experience to selfish card play may seem incongruent, but it works.

I've had games where drawing a monster of an appropriate level to fight took far too long. Seeing a player go from moderate Level 5-6 to Level 1 can be upsetting... though looting the body rarely is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Totally random. Flip over a card and do what it says. I gain one level? Great. I lose one level? Why? - Just because. So much fun... Can really drag at the end because everyone is beating on the leader which can unnecessarily prolong the game by another 20 minutes.  I have actually let people win this even though I could have foiled their attempt to reach level 10. But since I was at level 4, it seemed like a waste of time. You see, if one player wins, everyone wins because the game is over.

Each card has tons of text that must be read which really slows down the game. Dislike the art as well and I don't care much for the attemps at humor. The lack of any clear rules structure makes me insane. You can basically do anything you want, which coupled with the total randomness can be hugely frustrating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A light card game with lots of RPG jokes.  Only fun if you don't take it seriously, and treat it as a social experience rather than a thoughtful board game, because it is somewhat random and dependent on luck-of-thedraw, and is more about negotiation and diplomacy than strategic long-term planning (so if you don't like Fluxx, you probably won't like Munchkin either).  It's appeal is the interaction/negotiating, and the humor.  Munchkin is most amusing the first time around if you're not familiar with the cards/jokes, the jokes can wear thin with multiple playing.  For best results, form alliances or assist players to advance several levels before beginning the back-stabbing.  To shorten the game, use a time limit (eg one hour total, or 10 more minutes after a player reaches level 9), or create an End Game card which ends the game when turned up and initiates Player vs Player combat for tied players to determine a winner.  We play with a house rule that you can't curse other players or do nasty stuff until they're at least level 4.  Best with 4-5 players? 

Expansions owned:
[gameid=3943] - Adds new race: Orcs.  
[gameid=6606] - Adds new race: Gnome.  Adds new class: Bard.
[gameid=20660] - Adds: Steeds.  Even more Munchkin!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Not a broken game, just an obnoxious game.

You know 'that kid' who shows up, screams the entire time, and thinks he's the funniest person you'll ever meet?  Meet that, The Card Game.

You could get as much (if not more) enjoyment out of this game by just reading the cards.  The tropes they identify are real, and there's humor in that.  The game?  Not so much.  There's no reason to use your attacks until someone is an actual threat.  that means everyone reserves their shit and blasts the first person who could make it to 10.  There's usually enough left over that the second person also gets ass-blasted.  So, the best strategy is to happen to be the third person who could make it to 10, because then enough people will have exhausted themselves that you can win... an hour later.

Too long for a quick-laugh game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A game that's fun to play maybe once per year, and only if you play it for laughs. 

I've never seen a game more prone to disfunction. Aggressive, negative player interaction is encourage not only by many cards (which allow you to screw other players over), but also by the game itself (you are allowed to cheat and to bully other players, threatening to screw them over if they don't give you treasures). Games tend drag because people usually gang up on whoever seems to be running away at the moment, which can become frustrating for the current leader. As if all that wasn't bad enough, fortune plays an enormous role in Munchkin: you could draw powerful cards and build combos, or you could end up with a useless hand (high level monsters that you can't defeat nor throw against other players, multiple classes when you can only play one, etc.). Not my definition of an enjoyable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A funny card game with a ending that pins everyone against the almost-winner.

RATING: 7
The first few times I played this game I didn't like it much. But I was playing it wrong; I was playing to win. Now I play it just to have fun, with all of the weird combinations that come out, and trying to figure out how to stop the leader (often unsuccessfully). I don't play this game much, because I need the right group of people to play with (my wife, for example, refuses to play it with me), but when I get the right group together it can be a blast. Edit: My son, Nathan, loves this game and we have been playing it more often. We often choose just a couple of expansions to play with, and I have also set aside several cards we always play with, particularly those that defend against combat interference and give more hands and feet.

RATING: 5
I hesitate to call Munchkin a "good" game, but it certainly can be fun given the right group of people, especially if they are able to have fun with the silly D&D/fantasy puns in the cards.  The game is definitely a rip off, since you only get some cards and a D6 for $25 or so (Steve Jackson didn't even have the courtesy to include something to use a level counters in the box, meaning you'll need a bunch of pennies or something), but the game is incredibly easy and non-intimidating for larger groups of non-gamers, and can get pretty competitive and intense towards the end, even though there isn't a lot of skill involved.

RATING: 6
Played 1 time. I know that this might still be the novelty factor speaking, but I did like this game. It has tons of action cards, and interesting combat because players who meet a formidable monster can appeal to the other players for help with the incentive of rewards. Still largely a "take that" game, but with more players, it sort of balances out since all players need to keep each other in check. I enjoyed it well enough with 5 players, but further playing with less players will tell me a lot more about the game.

RATING: 6
I've played several different iterations of Munchkin over the years.  The base game is still, IMO, the best.  I bought a couple expansions, and I don't play with them. Its not as fun.

One downside is that if you're playing with all experienced players, 120 minutes is a rather low estimate for play time.  I played this on Thanksgiving.  The game lasted 3 1/2 hours, and we all knew what we were doing.  It could have even gone longer, but I decided to let it end and not play a card that would have delayed the victory longer.  6 players, all level 9, all with hands filled with things to stop others from killing a monster and winning.  It just lost its fun at the end.

RATING: 5
Pros
-My gateway game
-Fantasy theme parody, pro if you're into that

Cons
-Massive amount of king-making
-Being in first place early is a negative. Also leads to game dragging on and feeling very long for what you get done (from 30 mins to 3 hours)
-Very random. You draw from a deck of monsters ranging from level 1 to 20 (their level is also their strength)
-Very vague rules (I've seen many groups play it differently)
-Expansions add no new mechanics, overpriced game
-Low art quality

RATING: 4
A quick filler game that won't turn away non-gamers or casual gamers.

The rules are quite easy to understand and it's a "just jump right in and learn as you go" type of game.  The most fun in this game comes from the forced social interaction of forming alliances and back-stabbing.

Not a game to be used as the center piece of a game party, but easily a side game for late-comers, or the less addicted RPG/Strategy gamers of the group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Munchkins is a strange beast. Your distribution of goods is heavily luck-based, yet if you're good enough at bargaining/bluffing you can win at this game pretty consistently. It goes far too long for my tastes, and anything over 4 players creates too much down-time and too much chaos. 2 player doesn't work at all without completely overhauling the rules.

At 3 or 4 players this game can be good for some light-medium strategy. It's got a whole ton of luck, but if you get your favorite themed version it can be a good social game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
"Munchkin" est un curieux objet ludique. Par son ambiance, son thème, son humour, ses illustrations et ses règles un peu délirantes et variables selon les joueurs, il fait d'abord penser à un party game. Mais pour un party game, il est bien trop long. Le principal problème du jeu se tient dans ce paradoxe.

J'y ai beaucoup joué au lycée, en parallèle aux "Magic", deux univers assez différents donc, qui ne demandent pas la même approche. En tout cas, on s'éclatait bien, les cartes et même les règles sont vraiment amusantes et dans un esprit de dérision du jeu de rôle bienvenu. On ne respectait pas forcément ces règles, d'ailleurs, n'hésitant pas à les transgresser pour rendre le tout encore plus bordélique.

C'est donc l'aspect "party game" de la chose, avec comme point fort la sociabilisation autour de la table, le jeu étant plein d’interactions.. Mais le problème, comme mentionné plus haut, c'est que pour finir réellement une partie, ça prend un temps fou qui n'est pas à la mesure du plaisir pris. C'est du plaisir immédiat, qui doit s'arrêter rapidement, qui dure sur le court terme. Le jeu, lui s'étend sur le long terme et finalement, on s'ennuie de plus en plus, l'amusement laissant la place à une routine peu innovante et peu intéressante, laissant une énorme place au hasard sans qu'on puisse réellement le contrôler et les tours se ressemblant trop pour renouveler l'intérêt au cours de la partie.

Un jeu qui soulève d'agréable souvenirs, mais qui, malgré ses qualités, aurait mérité d'être retravaillé afin de faire correspondre esprit de jeu et temps de la partie. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

So glad to be rid of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
A totally random game. Players start with random equipment and random cards that might make them useful or useless. Each turn, the player draws a random card and if they're lucky enough to run into a monster they fight it or else they get to actually draw a card.
Players are supposed to discuss and bargain, but since each player wants the same things, there is minimal value to bargaining and bartering.
In a smaller game, the first player to reach the level ten goal will be bashed down by everyone and the second will walk to victory scott free. Larger games may be doomed to circle the drain endlessly as there are enough players to restock hand-sizes between beatdowns.

(3 plays, underestimate)
First Impressions: 2

RATING: 4
Un très bon jeu, rempli de momment mémorable. Mais comme tout jeux ayant pour objectif d'être drôle sa plus grande force en devient sa plus grande faiblesse. Plus on joue, moins le jeu est drôle, et quand on le joue aussi souvent que je l'ai fait ... il devient méchanique et inintéressant.

A very good game , filled with memorable momment . But like any game that aims to be funny in his greatest strength is his greatest weakness . The more you play , the less the game is funny, and when we play it as often as I did ... it becomes mechanical and uninteresting .

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fun, but for reasons that largely have nothing to do with the game itself. The worst sin Munchkin commits is length - it can just drag on FOREVER. ESPECIALLY if you play with one or more expansions added on to it. I seriously suggest you only ever play with one set at a time, and if you need to mix it up a bit, only do so with key groups of cards (e.g. adding the sharks from Munchkin Booty to the main set, and nothing else, works well). Also, this is not a game to treat with reverence - violate the cards, create your own, screw around with the rules. Really Munchkin falls into familiar problems as a game - kingmaker, "screw-the-leader", never ending stalemate. Like Killer Bunnies, you'll never enjoy this unless you turn your brain off, stop caring about the win condition, and just use it as a hang-outs enhancer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4

RATING: 3

If there was some sort of strategic choice to be made, it would be more interesting to me, but in most cases the choice is in the hands of other players which rarely feels all that good.

RATING: 8
Not bad at all,

Munchkin at first glance, in my opionion is kinda underwhelming. First off, the game is not so simple as it is intially portrayed. Some of the cards offer a bit of a chuckle, but kinda get old after a few games.  However, when you get going with a few other people and into the game, the hype suddenly becomes apparent. The game is a blast to play with three or more people. Helping people and back stabbing them afterwards. This game became an instant classic amongst my collection despite some of the subtle nuances.

RATING: 9
I don't understand the antipathy some people have for this game. Sure, there isn't deep strategy, and games can go a little long sometimes, but it's still one of my favorites. Things I like about it include:

  1. the cute and humorous cards

  2. that it's the best of the "take that" mechanic games I've played. It's enormous fun when people pile on to the leader.

  3. that it has the flavor of an RPG dungeon crawler without the need for a dense rulebook.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Munchkin was the gateway that got me into board games as an adult. I had a lot of fun playing it, and a purchased a lot of expansions. Unfortunately, I found that the game does not hold up well to multiple plays. 

I'm not talking about the jokes getting old or anything either. I still love the John Kovalic art, and I still chuckle at the jokes.

The problem is that you find that the game turns into a "kingmaker scenario" where there are multiple players sitting at level 9, and it's just a matter of which player you want to use all of your "take that" types of cards on, leaving the remaining player (whether you or your neighbor) as the de facto winner. 

Additionally, while Munchkin is thought of as a "Beer and Pretzels" casual game, pretty much after you play it a handful of times and play other games, you'll realize that there are better games out there that fall into the "Beer and Pretzels" casual category.

This has all yet to mention that when you do play with experienced players, what should be a 30 minute game literally drags on for 2 hours or more. I said above that I actually like the art and the jokes, but not for as long as this game drags on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
If you like tabletop gaming but want to avoid all that pesky roleplaying, Munchkin is the game for you. Hack 'n slash to your heart's content and grab as much loot as you can. It's definitely one of those games that gets much better with more people as a key component is getting other players to help defeat monsters (for a share of the treasure, of course). Steve Jackson has done a great job of keeping the mechanics and rules lighthearted and cultured an air of good natured competitiveness.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
People seem to have a real love-hate relationship with this game.  The tongue-in-cheek humor poking fun at fantasy games makes it a novelty, and it's simplicity is something to be admired.  However, at its core this is a classic game of screwing your opponent to win a victory.  Not a game for cry babies.  Also, I think Munchkin suffers from one too many expansions and nick-knacks (over 60 at last count).  UPDATE: I brought this one on vacation and unfortunately the game (and jokes) did not age well for me.  I don't anticipate doing much with the game at this point.
