=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Initial Rating: 7

I still think it could be fun to pull this one out for a quick, chaotic, humorous dungeon hack. The problem is that it isn't quick, or even just a bit too long. There is a real problem with both the beginning of the game where nothing productive seems to happen for a long time, and then the endgame that just drags on and on.
We had fun the first few times we played this, bu now I don't really expect playing this again without some kind of variant for a shorter game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Mainly luck based. On the other hand a very funny and entertaining game if played with the right (i.e.: cutthroat) people. Gets a bit stale after several plays.

Note: Since we play with all the sets owned combined, all plays are logged under Munchkin Blender.

RATING: 2
I've played this half a dozen times so far, mostly with my brothers.  It's light and funny and unique in that sometimes the best strategy isn't to win the game, but to have more fun messing with your opponents.  :-)  We added 2 expansions to the deck already just to make sure it doesn't get stale too fast.  Not the best game, but an enjoyable time with a group with the right joking mindset.  There isn't a whole lot of planning or strategy involved.  Just a screw your neighbor game with goofy curses and gotchas.

UPDATE: I'm pretty much done with this game.  I'm struggling to get my brothers to level up to more interesting games.  They might not be the best gaming group for that, though :)

UPDATE: Despite selling my copy of this game, my brother brought his own copy to Brother's (Game) Night.  Ugg!  We played Forbidden Desert, Pandemic and Munchkin... and Munchkin took longer to play than the first two COMBINED!  I can't stand it!  I'm desperate to get my brothers to level-up their gaming interest beyond this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
We only play Munchkin once a month, mainly because it can easily take 3 hours or more before somebody wins. While turns can be at times rather tedious, the endgame (the last hour or so) tends to be really exciting, with constant attacks and unexpected counterattacks. The deck (even when playing with expansions) is very well-balanced, and if you know when to play your cards you can easily stop somebody from winning (people often complain about this, but I think that this is Munchkin's stronger point). Adding expansions (and mixing cards from other munchkin games) is a must.

RATING: 7
My favorite thing about Munchkin is that you never know what you're going to get when you sit down to a game. Munchkin is a chaotic mess that shouldn't work as a game, but in the end it somehow does - provided you have a fun sociable group who aren't just focused on "win-win-win!" The game constantly forces players to either adapt or die, and dying is rarely that bad.

This was my gateway back into tabletop gaming. Even though I have played better games, this one will always remain dear.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I can see why it's popular with people that aren't as much into tabletop. There's a lot of comedy and there's some nice room for negotiation/working together in the early/mid game.

The problem is that this game basically devolves into people throwing everything they have at the one person about to win, which sometimes sets them back a few levels and just makes the game drag on.

I dislike when games overstay their welcome.

RATING: 4
On the same day that I decided to rate Munchkin after playing it once twelve years ago, I actually played it with players who were familiar with it. It wasn't so bad. In a sense it was a forerunner to later games like San Juan or RTFG, or even Glory to Rome in a way, but without the same level of structure. It was entertaining.

Deprecated: One of the most boring and unappealing games I have ever played. That said, I admit to formerly owning every Killer Bunnies deck, and I'm not sure they are conceptually much different. I ended up giving away KB for the same reason that I dislike Munchkin—fun idea but slow and lumbering (bunny) in practice.

RATING: 4
Take That!

Play fast, or it can be a slog. Nice for getting everyone involved, simple to start but with enough depth to keep people interested. Feels masturbatory. Every play is unique in cards but often homogenous and draw out in conclusion: Everyone is close to winning and whoever takes a turn where no one has cards to stop them wins. Rules modification is easy and works well, doubling monster levels, adjusting cards drawn, or changing the winning level.

Have Munckin 2,3,5,6,6.5,7,8

[b]Want to try with game timer[/b]

RATING: 4

RATING: 3
I know this is a classic, but it suffers from a couple problems:

First, it's very much an "In Joke" for players of D&D 1st Edition.  If you're not an RPG player then the jokes are just silly names.

Second: The "stab your buddy" portion of the game play can be pretty harsh.  If playing with younger kids it can be demoralizing.   When playing with adults it tends to drag on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Oft-maligned for being a game that is funny the first time and then loses it's appeal. Also for being a game that would be good if it lasted about 10 minutes instead of the 1-2 hours it can take (if you play with expansions particularly).

I like it. I agree it has replayability issues but it can definitely be a fun, light-hearted game to play. It can go on a little bit too long but if it's not fun any more I think people will just let the game end. It is expensive for what it is though.

RATING: 2
I just don't like it.  It's a shame, because most of my friends do, which means that I go off and do my thing (set up Descent, etc.) while they play.

While the first play was entertaining, Munchkin has too many things that detract.

- Wild luck swings
- Ganging up on the leader / kingmaking
- The inability to have control over basic character traits
- The inability to plan or strategize
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The original Munchkin is actually fairly weak compared to the sequels. The humor is a little weaker, the theme feels slightly disconnected and the card effects just aren't quite as fun. Several of the mini-expansions are really fantastic, though, and give the game a lot of what it's missing.  The deluxe edition is a really nice thing to have even for other editions - the board and the figures are fantastic and much nicer than always trying to improvise some way to track levels.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
How many times have I played munchkin? Too many, I'm sure, and yet all always play one more time. By the time I got around to Munchkin, I was well aware of its reputation as a madness inducing take that game scantily clad in card art, rpg elements and juvenile humor. I had already been introduced to games such as Lords of Waterdeep, Game of Thrones, and Eldritch horror. This was undeniably a step down. And yet, sometimes a scrap in the dust is just what the doctor ordered. I despise this game at 6 players, but at 4 it really can be a lot of fun. However, I never end a game of Munchkin ready for another bout, and usually it takes at least a month for me to forget about the game's less desirable features in favor of its entertainment value. Eventually though, I always do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
A very good entry level game. Simple to teach and play, requires little strategy, high luck base on what comes out of the deck.

Very group specific, fun with a light hearted group at the end of the night. Absolutely horrible with competitive people, vindictive people, or rules Nazis as some cards are very open to interpretation. 

Game can be painful if you don't acquire monsters, looting the room turns are far too common. Nothing really fun happens until the last few rounds as you try and save the offensive cards to the end as they are hard to come by.

Ok game, there are better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Ray

Edicion antigua (sepia) adquirida en compra conjunta (obsequio) con defectos. Reclamado a Edge.

Adquirida edicion nueva (color) usada. 

Varias expansiones adquiridas por Ray y otras Regalo a Ray de 2015. 

El famoso juego de cartas de "mata monstruos, roba el tesoro, apuñala a tus amigos". y efectivamente de eso anda la cosa: matar algunos bichos, robar algunos tesoros y putear bastante al projimo. 

el tono de humor del juego es chispeante, el juego es original y dinamico (especialmente considerando el hecho de ser, o al menos basarse en, un dungeon crawler). Pero literalmente, en ocasiones es excesivamente absurdo sobre todo cuando otros jugadores participan "puteando" para ayudar al monstruo y que derrote al jugador para bajarle el nivel. tampoco ayuda que en ciertas ocasiones de interaccion las reglas no son claras y dejan la patata caliente al propio jugador. 

dependiendo del grupo puede ser risas aseguradas toda la tarde o una pesadilla espantosa. 

A mi particularmente: lo encuentro gracioso un rato, pero como juego de mesa no me llena. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

This is one of those "screw over the other players" games in a big, big way, and I like cooperative games because I can be a bit of a bad sport when, for example, I get knocked from level 9 all the way back to level 1 by my kids teaming up to screw me over.  So, I have to insist on moderation with this very uncooperative game (if moderation means only playing it three times in a row).  But it is undeniably fun and clever and my kids sure love it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Munchkin: 15 Minutes of Fun Crammed into 2 Hours

Fairly amusing, but not a lot here in the way of strategy. You win by being the first to gain 9 levels, which you do by winning fights, which is easier at higher levels. So it has a runaway winner problem, while at the same time having no strategic choices to balance (just gain levels as fast as possible). The other player can gang up to a degree, but this only goes so far. My suspicion is that my rating would drop further after more plays.
UPDATE: Rating dropped. It's way too long for how much game there is.

RATING: 6.5
  Played this a few times. The combat dynamic of just comparing two numbers seems... well too simple. The first few turns, it's almost impossible to start leveling up. Some player ALWAYS gets left behind, and charity doesn't help that much.
   Admittedly, that's part of it's charm. I'm always surprised how much player interaction gets generated (and admittedly, the game is really freaking funny). It's not an all-the-time game, but a decent one to play with friends who aren't deep into gamers. 
   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
PL: Chyba najgenialniejsza spośród gier karcianych w które grałem. Świetnie komponuje się z piwem. Obrazki Kovalica, jak i żartobliwe opisy często powodują rechot wśród graczy. Gra o tym co tygryski lubią najbardziej: kradnij, kłam, oszukuj, spiskuj i nie daj się nakryć lub wyrolowac innym graczom. Sama podstawa z czasem się nudzi, bo zna sie już wszystkie karty. Pudełko aż się prosi o jakieś przegródki czy wytłoczki na karty. Mimo tych małych wad polecam każdemu, szczególnie osobom znającym klimat RPG.

EN: Probably the most ingenious of the card games that I played. Created to play when drinking beer. Pictures made by Kovalic and humorous descriptions often cause croaking among the players. A game is about what Tiggers like best: steal, lie, cheat, conspire and don't get caught by other players. This basic edition becomes little boring after a few games, because it is easy to remember all cards. Box cries out for some partitions or stampings for the cards. Despite these small flaws would recommend it to anyone, especially to those familiar with RPG atmosphere.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]tl;dr[/b] — When played by 3 or 4 RPG geeks inside 45 minutes (utilizing all "Faster Play" Rules) this is an absolute lark as a storytelling/party game; with the wrong number of the wrong people with the wrong mindset in the wrong timeframe it's absolute hell.

[size=10][BGCOLOR=#FFCC66][COLOR=#663300][b]O[/b][/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][/size][COLOR=#663300]nce upon a time, when I was 13, we played [i]D&D[/i] all night long at a slumber party.  Around midnight we killed the whiniest kid's character, took all his magic stuff, drew a pentagram on his chest with Hershey's Chocolate Syrup (in the handy squeeze bottle) and threw him into the swimming pool.  [i]Munchkin[/i] is exactly like that.  ~[/COLOR]

[size=12][b][i]Munchkin[/i] is a party game.[/b][/size]

[i]Whether it's fun or not depends entirely on the group.[/i]  

It's a stupid-fun activity, not a strategy game where players capable of 4D chess will prevail.  Dumb luck and above-the-table whining have far more to do with who wins than skill or intellect.*  Yes, the jokes are lowbrow and get old.**  The standard rules can make the game overstay its welcome by a factor of 10.  But with the right group and right mindset this is good fun inside of 45 minutes.  Just add beer, pretzels and a sailor's vocabulary.

[size=7]*Not entirely true.  There is a [i]teeensy bit[/i] of strategy in building a hand and tableau that can threaten a sudden win from Level 6 if you know what you're doing...

**The intended audience—RPG nerds & the con crowd—actually appreciate the repetition.[/size]

[size=12][b]It's fun as long as it's fun.[/b][/size]

[i]Kill it when it turns.[/i]

[i]Munchkin[/i]'s fatal flaw is game length.  It kicks ass for about 30 minutes, and then everybody starts to get antsy, looking for the end that never seems to come—a cool, refreshing wave that rises up and curls white with feathery tips of sweet release... only to recede again as someone thwarts someone else's lunge for Level 10.  Over.  And over.  [i]And over[/i]...  Until someone finally sneaks an exhausted win and the game is unceremoniously forearm-wiped back into the box and hurled into the closet to cries of "Why did you make us play that?" and "Never again—no, I [i]really mean it[/i] this time."

[COLOR=#CC0033][b]SUDDEN ASIDE:[/b]  [i]A Note to Designers.[/i]  Every game is only good for so long—find out where that is and then design your game to come to a satisfying conclusion juuust under that threshhold.  This will make people cry "Let's do that again!", shuffle up and go—instead of "Thank God [i]that's[/i] over," shuffle off and [i]go[/i].  Think of it as analogous to the physical limitations of masturbation and you're on the right track.[/COLOR]

So, can [i]Munchkin[/i] reach a satisfying climax before chafing sets in?  It can, but most of the time it doesn't.  Hideous time dilation lurks deep in its DNA—everything possible must be done to prevent its expression.

Here's what we do:

[b]1.  Play with 3 or 4 players [i]only[/i].[/b]
With 5 it's a grind; 6 is miserable.  Keep it short and sweet with fewer players.

[b]2.  Use the most current version of the rules.[/b]
Four Doors & four Treasures as the starting hand (and when returning from death).

[b]3.  Use ALL "Faster Play" Rules.[/b]
Add [i]Phase 0—Listen At The Door[/i]; [i]Loot The Room[/i] for a Treasure instead of a Door; win is shared with helper, regardless of helper's level.

[b]4.  Start at Level 2 (or 3!).[/b]
Why not?  Munchkin, &c.

[b]5.  Time limit/call it the moment it blows.[/b]
We usually play to 30 minutes, maybe 45 if it's a particularly good session.  But the moment anyone is not enjoying themselves and would rather do anything else, we call it after one more round (The [gameid=3837] Rule).  If no one hits Level 10 by then the winner is determined by highest total combat bonus from cards in play, with level as a tiebreaker.

[microbadge=1358]

The [COLOR=#CC0033]retired OG set[/COLOR] that used to be for stranger game nights, camping & unwashed children:

[GAMEID=1927] (2003 printing)
[GAMEID=3943]
[GAMEID=6606]

This is the BEST setup—just enough variation without any excess bloat.  It's also my favorite set from a good-times/nostalgic-pizza-grease perspective.

[imageid=1488345 small inline][imageid=1488344 small inline][imageid=2671298 small inline]

Deluxe, Holiday Surprise, Holidazed, Christmas Lite, Fairy Dust

[b]Technicolor curb-stomp[/b] AKA [B]MEGAMUNCHKIN[/B]
Deluxe, 2, 3, 6, 6.5; curated cards from 4, 5, 7 (Cheat With Both Hands) & 8; Game Changers
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[i]Munchkin[/i] is not a strategy game.  It will not work for those who must clench a bolus of control in their anal-retentive sphincters.  

It's a social interaction coupling device.  

It's a party game.  

In that regard it does a decent job and gets anywhere from a 5 on up to a 10, depending on the group dynamic.

It's best when played inside 45 minutes by 3 or 4 goofy, old-school fantasy RPGers.

:gg:

RATING: 7
[B]MEGAMUNCHKIN[/B] — [COLOR=#FF0000]*COMPLETE*[/COLOR]

It turns out I already own [i]four other[/i] fantasy [i]Munchkin[/i] sets—which makes me either stupid, rich or duped.  I think I'll go with "hopelessly funtropic" & "shame-impaired" instead.

So why yet another?  Well, the original is enjoying its hard-won retirement as a shelf toad, the second is "pure sepia" from the era before full-color cards, the third is specifically frosted for Christmas holiday play, and the fourth is in the camping bin where it gets begripped by the filthy hands of wild children.  This one, though, was conceived via the hideous congress of my anal retentive tendencies and my irrational love for the game—[-]I wanted a set that could absorb and utilize all the various small expansions that SJG poots out with maddening regularity[/-].  [COLOR=#FF0000]*DONE*[/COLOR]

The [BGCOLOR=#000000][c] [/c][COLOR=#FF0000]TE[/COLOR][COLOR=#FF9900]CH[/COLOR][COLOR=#FFCC00]N[/COLOR][COLOR=#00CC00]I[/COLOR][COLOR=#0099FF]C[/COLOR][COLOR=#0066FF]OL[/COLOR][COLOR=#9933FF]OR[/COLOR][c] [/c][/BGCOLOR] curb-stomp set:

RATING: 7
Excellent card game.  My 13 yr old loves playing and back stabbing.  Now, if only she would learn to wait until after the 3rd round to do so, maybe she'd have some allies and a chance at winning.  The wife does not like it that much but she will play if pressed.  I can take it or leave it.  It's really fun with large groups who are comfortable attacking and being turned on.   I can see the main flaw, as stated by others, is that it could become very difficult to win when playing with experienced folks.  This is when the game becomes quite a bit more strategic and holding onto the right cards becomes key to winning.

RATING: 4
If you like the style of humor Munchkin uses, it's fun to read through the cards - I find about half of the cards to be pretty funny.  However, I don't particularly enjoy the game.  It's too random, for one thing.  You can't acquire levels and loot until you're lucky enough to run into a monster you can actually beat, which makes the early turns frustrating.  I find that the game falls apart completely if you have 5 or more players, since there are so many people to gang up on you when you get close to victory.  I think with some tweaks to the rules it could be made into a much better game, rather than just a set of joke cards masquerading as a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An old classic! This game brought me into the world of board games, so I remember it fondly. The game starts off slow and everyone is more than willing to help each other defeat monsters until someone reaches Level 6. As that person climbs up the levels to Level 9, other players pull out as many cards as possible to beef up monsters and reduce the highest level player's combat strength. This unfortunately prolongs the game because it's only a matter of time before everyone else joins them at Level 9. At that point, if people haven't already used up all their offense cards, the game is pretty much determined by what card each player draws when they kick open the door, each desiring a low-level monster, which would be easy to defeat and difficult for everyone else to beef up, or a filler card that allows them to play a low-level monster from their hand. By the time someone draws/plays a low level monster, players must decide--should I continue to fight for victory or end this 3-hour period of torture? And of course, everyone chooses the former.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Getting a little old, to many expansions. By the time you are a level 5 you can beat a level 20 monster without help.

RATING: 2
This is probably one of the first board games I've ever bought as a child. It was fun but as time went on it lost it's shine. The thing that makes me hate this game now is that it takes all the fun of adventuring and role-playing that you are promised in DnD and makes it insufferable. A game that starts out kind of fun becomes terribly agitating as people attempt to kill the leader over and over again. To make matters worse, the game seems to only serve to prolong it's play time until finally one person decides they've had enough and just lets someone win. If I had to make a list of all the games I'd recommend I'd learn new games just so I could push Munchkin farther down.

RATING: 7

The backstabbing nature of the game can cause arguments.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Ideal Players: 5-8

Description: Kick down doors to find monsters, curses, and treasure. Be the first to level 10 to win in this D&D parody game.

Pro: Funny art. Quick and easy gameplay. Evokes the spirit of old-school D&D--killing things and taking their stuff. Success or failure not determined by dice. Promotes beat-on-the-leader mentality.

Con: Lacking in choices and complexity. Gets old after a few plays (although the expansions help with that). Monsters tend to be overpowered or underpowered. The game would be better if encounters scaled with levels (getting cooler classes, treasure, etc. as you get higher level).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Light, relaxing, and funny game. Had to get some expansions for variety, but still awesome just out of the box.

RATING: 7
What can I say about munchkin which wasn't already said? Most people either love it or hate it, though it's beyond me how can you hate a game that's got a Resident Weavil (you can't resist the evil of the weavil), or the Duck of Doom (you should have known better). Either way, it's a light game that still might bring to an end a fare share of friendships (depending on how firecly you play). I Found it to be very kind to starting or non-gamers, and they can pick it up and enjoy it relatively easily. It gets messy with all the expansions, and might make the game drag on a bit. All in all, a good bang for his buck!

RATING: 2
Munchkin has some cards that are funny to read the first time. Beyond that, there is little to recommend here. The game is almost entirely determined by luck of the draw and the whims of the players. It drags on way too long as players who are about to win constantly have their progress taken away from them.

The popularity of this game shows there is a market for games featuring lots of randomness and take that mechanics. Some find this enjoyable - I loathe such games and, as a result, actively avoid playing Munchkin.

RATING: 2
Any game where you start off weak and must face a progression of increasingly difficult tasks in order to grow stronger and eventually win must have a mechanism to assure that you face the trials in a reasonable order.  Munchkin fails miserably at this.  See Formidable Foes for an example of this done correctly.

At least Munchkin has neat John Kovalic art, and the roleplaying jokes are funny the first couple of times through the deck.

RATING: 4
This game was fun for about about 5 minutes until the humor factor wore out.  Once the humor is gone, the gameplay is just boring.  There are much better RPG inspired games than this.

Also there is too much "screw the leader".  Sure, everyone wants to slam on the winner to stop them, but Muchkin takes it to a new extreme.  The only way to win is to grind through everyone's hoser cards, and hope they finally run out when it's your time to attempt winning.

RATING: 3.5
My gaming group seems to really like this one, but for whatever reason, it just really hasn't been enjoyable to me.  I'm not sure whether it's because Take That games aren't a favorite genre for me, or that the game is extremely lightweight and often mindless, or that it just is one of those games that seem to bring out the worst in people, but I simply don't have a good time playing it.  Obviously many people do, so it's likely just taste and not game quality, but I really do think this game is a take it or leave it kind of game.  I rate it a 3.5/10 because I'll still play it when it gets brought to the table, but I can't say I'd ever actively choose to play this game myself.  I recommend playing it once or twice before buying- you may love it, but you also may be extremely disappointed in it.

RATING: 6
I think the fun of this game depends a lot of the people you play it with.  But then again, if these folks are that much fun, wouldn't you have fun playing or doing a variety of things that evening? Ok, that's a bit unfair. The game encourages lightheartedness with its humor and does encourage interactivity, even some negotiation (when you're trying to recruit people to help you defeat strong monsters).

A good game with the right mix (and not everyone will like this game).  However, I think it just stretches out a bit too much.  There's *too* many mechanics that seem to work to prolong the game, by propping up the trailing players by passing discards their way, to the massive 'attack the leader' effect.

RATING: 7.5
Bash the door. Slay the monster. Steal the loot. Under anyone else, this could have been a simple dungeon crawl game using cards instead of books and dice -- but not for Steve Jackson. Jackson's loads it with humour (Level 1 Potted Plant!) coupled with John Kovalic's art (Coat Of Arms is literally a coat with extra arms) give it that extra oomph to turn it into a light and enjoyable party game that moves so fast it demands all players remain involved.

BIG PLUS: easy to learn, sense of humour
PLUS: all ages
MINUS: you can get bored with it after a while

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Munchkin is a lighthearted, very simplified sort of game that takes its cues from the Role Playing genre. There is no actual role-playing here, just a decent concept for introducing casual gamers to the realm of Role Play tropes while managing to get a chuckle from experienced Role players once in a blue moon. 
If you're looking for a deep tactical and/or strategic gaming experience, look elsewhere. If, however, you're interested in a game where anyone can win and no one is out of contention at any point during the course of a game, then go ahead and pick it up... better yet; I'll trade it to you. 

Don't get me wrong, I do give it props for being so simple. Also, Munchkin is nothing if not cheap and endlessly expandable -- and it can provide a few laughs if you happen to find that style of humor favorable. Keep in mind that even if you do, the humor wears off after a short while, so you must expand at some point, lest the game become stale in this way. 

I gave Munchkin a 4 mostly because I would have expected to play this game more than I have after owning it for so long, but it never leaves its dust-covered little box on the bookshelf because something else always seems more appealing to me. The Role playing theme should be right up my alley... it should be funnier to me... yet, for whatever reason, it just isn't.

I recognize that the series is insanely popular and quite well-known. Chances are, even your most casual board gaming friends will have played it or at least heard of it, which means they might just be interested enough to sit down and play it, while you begin to sell them on the games in your collection that you wish they WOULD try, because you know they'd just love it if they gave it a chance. 
Munchkin is what I'll affectionately coin a "background game" from here on out, so named for its ability to progress without much concentration required from its participants insofar as any significant decision making, because, ultimately, things can take a quick turn for the better or the worse regardless of how well you have played thus far. It' indecently random, which, for me, doesn't make it an enjoyable experience... ever, win or lose. Lastly, I was really annoyed that it doesn't include some sort of a character level counter in box... instead it asks you to "find" things in your house that you have lying around... use your smartphone, etc... Really??? Come on. I know it's trying to be cheap, but wow.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Yes, it can result in a lot of laughter (especially when debating rules - not), but it grossly overstays its welcome and every game seems to end the same way (leader gets dragged down and second place cruises easily to victory). Nope.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Incredibly over-rated, this semi-party game is best played with people you haven't played it with before, and preferably non-gamers entirely. The fun of this game lies entirely in reading the cards and the attendant silliness. And it was fun the first two or three times I played, when I would have rated it about a 7 for fun factor and humour.

But the mechanics are dumb, the game usually ends up in beating on the leader until everyone hits level 9, when the winner is determined by who happens to pick up a weak monster to kill, or when everyone else ran out of "take that" cards. Occasionally a game is determined earlier by even more stupefying luck in one players favour.

Do not play with less than five players.

I give this a 5/10 for initial fun factor games, and still being able to have a decent-ish game with non-gamer friends. But you can do better!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Love It or Hate It - Munchkin is one of those games that must be played with the right group and the right frame of mind.
Play this game with strangers or serious-types and it wont be fun at all - it is too random for that.
However, play it with your family or gaming group (especially if you are a roleplaying group) and it will an absolute blast - mix in a few drinks and them everyone can start to enjoy the awesome combinations of equipment, races, classes, trap cards and monsters and really get into the theme. 
Sure there is the randomness, but if the players realise that its not who wins that is important but the fun that is had during the game, then everyone will be a winner
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The original screw-over-your-friends game.  You are a human with no class, unless you play a class or a race. You equip some item and you bang down some dungeon doors in search of loot. More often than not you will encounter a monster, that monster however is much much stronger than your puny sling of +1. What is an explorer to do? Ask for help from those around you maybe they'll help, in exchange for some of the booty. Or maybe (probably more likely) someone else would like to see you fail and play a card that will help the monster. This game has about a trillion different ways for either of those two situations to happen and the expansions just add to the goofiness. Dead simple to learn game, setup is less than 5 minutes. Strongly recommend buying the deluxe version as it comes with figurines (which are just for cosmetics, they are fun though) and comes with a board that is used to count level. Casual game, could even be played at parties with some varied rules (level up to 7 or 8 instead of 10). Lots of people hating on this game but in its own right it is still a lot of fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
hideous art and jokes that weren't funny 25 years ago, great.  would rather gnaw my own arm off than get trapped playing this again, good thing there are six hundred licensed versions filling up shelves in stores.

RATING: 3

My wife learned to play easily, but didn't get half the references or think that most of it was funny, for instance. It's kind of like a Will Ferrell movie - if you don't go in expecting fine cinema, you'll have a great time!

RATING: 7
I'm a fan of Munchkin. I've spent numerous nights staying up til the wee hours of the morning giggling away with my sister or friends over lengthy silly titles like "I'm a super munchkin dwarf elf wizard with a really impressive title, a big rock, a pointy hat of power, and boots of butt kicking. I'm fighting a level two perfectly ordinary bunny rabbit that if I don't defeat it, I am dead, even if it was just an ordinary bunny." 

Not all games should be taken seriously. This one is all about the humor, interaction and light hearted, get in tune with your silly side, fun.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
While I am not a Munchkin diehard, purchasing every game variant and expansion, I am also not a Munchkin hater.  I enjoy the game for what it is but recognize that this is not a true war or boardgame. There is strategy to a degree but this, more than most other games I own, is just silly, nonsensical, and random, with reasonable plays being crushed by bad card draws and suboptimal play rewarded by drawing a level one monster towards the end of the game, really screwing things up. 
I primarily play with power gamers, which seem like an odd fit for this game. Our Munchkin games typically follow a pretty cautious pattern with a few players catching good luck and charging into the lead, a larger gaggle hanging in the middle, and a player or two that cannot catch a break and languish far behind. Eventually, one of the front runners makes a charge for level 10 and all hell breaks loose. The first player knocking on level 10's doorstep seldom wins, and at that point it is anyone's game. While the second player to make a run has an advantage, even the lone straggler player can win as "screw you" cards are played against those assailing the game's victory condition. 
This may seem pointless and stupid and perhaps it is but I play the game infrequently enough that it has not grown old or stale and the cards still make me laugh. I can see where repeated playings in a short period would detract from enjoyment of this game but that has not happened to me as of yet. It may not be a war/board game but for what it is, it is pretty darn funny. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
I played my first game of it with just my husband, but it was still fun! Three to six players is totally a better group to have for this quick card game. It should be fun for RPGers AND non-RPGers alike!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is fun. It is basically pure luck and understanding of the use of the cards, but it is so funny to screw your opponent , especially when he doesn't expect it.
Very recommended for youth from 11 to 16.
The game becomes better after 5 or 6 gameplays, when you know how to use the cards. The first 5 gameplays can be a bit difficult, but once you know the cards and how to play them, this game is absolutely good ( especially with the expansion " The need for speed".
There are more tactics and strategy in the game than you would expect, but you will learn these only after enough gameplays ( 5 or 6 at least).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
On its own, this is, without expansions, it's a fun light card game, which can be a great introduction to the hobby for tabletop RPG gamers. Parodies a lot of RPG tropes, so it can be a blast to play if in the right mood. This is, in the mood of playing a humorous take-that luck fest.

Thankfully, while novelty wears off, if players are familiar with the rules, 3 or 4 player games last 50 minutes tops. Can end sooner, but once you reach the 40 minute mark, one player is almost guaranteed to snowball out of control, thus ending the game. It's like the game had a timer built inside its mechanisms.

Expansion, while have their fair share of funny cards, break the "balance". This is, it's no longer so certain someone will snowball out of control past the 40 minute mark, making the game drag. And more than an hour of Munchkin can be extremely boring.

Rating: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Number of players:
:thumbsup:3~4
:thumbsdown:2,5~6

This seems to have been fixed in later printings (along with the tongue-in-cheek reference to cheating in the rules).

RATING: 2

You spend 30 min at level 1, then the game speeds up to level 8 in 1h, and then you spend another 30 min stuck at level 8 or 9. Whoever plays when others do not attack cards anymore win.

That game is a 8 for the first games, but I just hate it now and can't bear to give it more than 4.

RATING: N/A
As with any Munchkin game, you should metaphorically stab each other in the back to get the full experience. The name of the game is "Munchkin" after all ... if no one's going to be Munchkinly, what's the point? There isn't much of a game when everyone is constantly nice to each other. Stick with co-op games if you're averse to harmless and lighthearted contention. Anyway, it's all just good, clean, dirty fun.

There's not a big lot of strategy here, and luck is the queen, but then, it's so much fun!!!

RATING: 6
This is a very silly "take that!" kind of card game. Very little skill involved and a lot of luck but can be quite enjoyable with the right group. A problem with this game is that the game can drag on and on because of unlucky card draws and people just being downright mean. Usually all players gang up on the player who is winning and makes there life miserable! Also, I am a big rule-follower and the rulebook states that if there is a rule discrepancy to hash it out amongst the players...my worst fear! A little too silly for me most of the time.

RATING: 7
Silly, somewhat cutthroat fun.  Can be a high learning curve, and some people are turned off by the complex calculations of levels, items, and various "screw you"/"help you" cards that can all go into a particular monster fight.  And if people start running low on interactive cards the game sometimes seems to crawl.

RATING: 5
My updated review:
This one's taken a hard fall... We used to play it quite a bit, but I don't want to play it anymore. For me, it's too lucky, and you get punished for being the first player to get close to victory. Plus the game can get really lengthy for what it offers...


My initial review (originally gave it an eight):
Munchkin is the best game if you like to start arguments! The rules are always contradicting themselves, there's a lot of interpretation needed, and that's where the arguments start.
Anyway, a very funny game with great artworks and a lot of stupid cards! (A big geek culture is needed to get the jokes...)
The negative part is that it can take a long time to play, especially when you have the expansions. We had some very long games, up to 8 hours long... Where everyone finally gets bored and very tired.
.... But playing with the expansions adds lots of fun stuff, I can't play without them!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Glad this exposes people to the hobby but I'm sad for those that think Munchkin is the hobby. It's a bearable game at the start but toward the end it just drags on forever.

But, even beyond the jokes (which are all funny the first time), there's at least a marginal game here, which really can generate some enjoyment.

Could also be considered at Xmas party with cousins/family members... The rules are 'intentionally' vague as to let players argue like he*l like real RPG Munchkin types usually do. Yeah, it's cheap in every sense... Tons of expansions will probably be printed but dont expect anything different than a fully chaotic,  humorous 'kill me-kill you' type of game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Munchkin has it's rare moments, but it's just not a good game. The rules are poorly defined, the game is inexplicably long, and the randomness frequently punishes those who are behind more than it impedes those who are ahead. It also has the worst excuse for a catch-up mechanic I've ever seen in a game.

Once you've seen someone win a game by defeating a potted plant for the last level, you've seen it all. Play Cosmic Encounter instead, there's more variety, the rulebook is actually more coherent, and it's a better mix of silly randomness and take that elements.

RATING: 8

It is all about D&D (or the associated Ninja/Cthulhu/Vampire/Star Trek themes.)

RATING: 4.5
We brought this over to the extended family's place for Thanksgiving and it *caught fire*. Our non-gamer friends and relatives loved it, played it over and over, and asked if they could borrow it when it was time for us to leave. In the right group (one whose members have a passing knowledge of D&D but who lack the experience of more in-depth games, and who are high energy and relatively competitive), it can be lots of fun. My opinion of this game went up after Thanksgiving weekend. For me, though, it's still too luck-based and its replayability is limited.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The success/enjoyment of Munchkin, in my opinion, is entirely dependent on the group playing it.  You need a group willing to back-stab without taking personal offense (excluding short-term grudges, of course), and really get into the spirit of the game.  Without these qualities, Munchkin is mediocre at best.  With the right group, this can and has been the funnest game I've ever played.

It also helps to have the appropriate "flavor."  Not as fun if you're not into the theme

Eventually decided it wasn't getting enough love anymore, and passed it on to a household that would actually play it.

RATING: 2
[microbadge=670]

The game is supposed to be a joke, right?  Like, you're not actually trying to create a fantasy adventure experience; you're supposed to be [i]mocking[/i] the fantasy adventure experience.  Yet I've seen people go deep and serious about this game.  I can't comprehend.

The game takes way too long.  It's way too random, with way too much down time, and way too little payoff in the time-to-fun conversion.  I respect how there are so many varied expansions/sequels covering basically every possible RPG theme which are all compatible and can be mixed together... but it's just not fun.

RATING: 6
Type: 3-6 player Competitive/Cooperative card-based monster crawl.

Best with: 4-6
Weight: Light
Duration: 45-90 minutes
Notes:
card-based game, but very little text or complexity
light-hearted for RPG geeks
heavy screw-your-neighbor mechanics, especially for someone who gets ahead early
can bog down late as people dog-pile on those in the lead
luck largely based on card draws, both for monsters and treasures
pretty high interaction, including open-ended bargaining for help or item trades


Similar games in my collection: This game is somewhat unique as a light, mildly competitive card-based game. Chez Geek is similar, that I do not own. Smash Up, sort of.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
In this card game, every player is against every other player. Make no mistake, it will become nasty.
The goal of the game is to reach level 10 before the others, but the focus is how you deal with them. You can resort to any means in order to obtain what you want: pleading, trading, deceiving, threatening...
You can intervene in fights to hinder your opponent, or to help him (in exchange of something). Or you can do both.
Discussions are inevitable. Dirty tricks even more so.
The only flaw is a certain randomness of the game system.
Try it, but only with friends which are capable of taking the worst with a laugh and a joke.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
Sure, it's not the game with the most depth in my collection, but few games beat it when it comes to cheer fun!

RATING: 3
As with munchkin quest. poor. sad disappointed. I could have given up on games at this point altogether based on this.

"This was one of the games I got on my first foray into this rediscovered hobby following Nuclear war. This choice was based on blind recommendations and my first experience of how bad those recommendations could be. From the reviews this sounded great - ok there were some dissenters but maybe they were wrong. There are always dissenters even on good games. They weren't wrong. I got this at the same time as the munchkin quest and I really should not have bothered. Dull lifeless lame jokes far too much effort for what was a joke anyway. Clearly the 'joke' was supposed to be on things like Descent but since that is awesome it falls flat."


Played this again with 3 a year later and although its not as bad as I remembered it was still disappointing.

I think the thing was that I was expecting awesome and I got meh.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.5
This game can take forever to get moving. It requires a miracle for someone to get powerful enough to make real headway because the only real strategy available is to bash whoever happened to luck into the lead at the current time. Once someone manages to luck through all the bashing there's not much you can do about it but wait for the next hour or so to end.

It smacks of haphazardness with differing terminology for the same thing i.e. one monster card says +5 against Dwarves but another monster says Elves are at -4. A nit pick but still not encouraging.

It's a real shame Steve Jackson is content to shoot out dozens of iterations of the Munchkin dreck instead of producing games of the quality SJ Games used to offer.

While I respect Kovalic's talent as an artist I just don't enjoy his style.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Objectively, it's a type of game I would like:
+ fantasy-themed; going on an adventure
+ turn-based
+ collecting things, having weapons, armor, magical items, accessories
+ kinda like an RPG; having gear, leveling up

But when I play it, I get competitive, and I get mad when people target me, and I can't target them back. Like when Chynna targeted me, and I wasn't allowed to target her back. As a side note, I'm pretty sure when people target me (in a non-friendly way), then I get upset. I didn't like that Ryan keeps winning; it kinda seems inevitable that he'll win, and it doesn't make it fun. I guess I don't like it when people team-up.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I have the deluxe board version and have the Axe expansion. I am still seeking the most appropriate group to play with as I accept the warnings from previous reviewers regarding how receptive they will be to the nature of the game. 
On reading the reviews it appears that the most common criticism relates to the length of the game and in particular the " Dog-Piling" on the level 9 player by the group which usually thwarts his/ her ambitions and clears the way for an unoposed win by the next player in line as additional monster cards are depleted etc. 
I feel ill equipped to give any suggestions that may serve to overcome this problem as I still haven't played the game. However, the time issue could surely be addressed by perhaps imposing certain " House Rules" such as; players begin on level 2 -3 ( At least a  go down a level card could be used ) Now with particular reference to the assaults by the group on the level 9 player; perhaps if these interventions had to be qualified by a Dice throw the prospective winner has half a chance ( or more ) of succeeding. An example could be that I have 2-3 cards that will spoil the level 9 player's hopes but have to throw the Die once and beat the counter throw. Should I lose then I cannot introduce any card, play then passes to the next challenger etc. Should there be 5-6 players a rule could prohibit more than 3 challengers ( first come first served basis ) 
Although I haven't played yet and may love or hate the game when that time comes; I get the general impression from Mr Jackson that he would not  object to any improvisation that could or would improve our enjoyment of the game. After all Fun is just the thing to have!!
I hope this helps folks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Edycja rozszerzona

RATING: 3

RATING: 7
A large variety of cards, a decent amount of strategy along with a bit of luck, Munchkin is a lot of fun to play. Few complaints, like the very heavy reading and math nearly every turn and I have gotten into many arguments over vagueness on cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game will always have a place in my heart as we discovered it during Superstorm Sandy where it provided countless hours of ‘light’ entertainment, (pun intended). Ever since the electricity came back on I started being over it. I definitely believe it is worth to play a few rounds and chuckle at the RPG/Geek Culture references, but in a lot of ways it feels a lot more like reading a funny comic with friends than playing a game. That is fine, but there are only so many times you can reread the same pages and still enjoy yourself. Of course that is the reason why there are countless expansions to keep things fresh. After trying quite a few of the expansions the pattern became clear and it took increasingly less plays to grow tired of the new cards.

For my tastes the mechanics are filled with too much randomness and positive feedback. Too often someone quickly turns into an ever more powerful Übermunchkin while everyone else is just hoping that the Duck of Doom will provide them with better hands early in the next game. Good filler as long as it’s new to you, grows old fast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Too long, too random. Great fun with the right group of people. If you have some hardcore roleplayers, this game can be a catalyst for great storytelling and reminiscing about your old D&D campaigns, at which point the game no longer matters.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Man, I used to love Munchkin. My group played it incessantly for a couple of months, and then gradually lost interest in it. For me, that came down to a combination of too much randomness and a very poor time:fun ratio -- it's too long to count as filler, and not satisfying enough to stand in for a deeper game.

Kovalic's art and the overall flavor are the best thing about Munchkin, and the only thing that would bring me back to it at this point. There just isn't enough else there that I enjoy.

---

Played it again, many years later, and it's still awful.

RATING: 9

It's a permanent top5 game for me. But really BGG? Munchkin is basically gateway version of CE, let's be honest. That's how Steve Jackson made it. Why hate it for that? I prefer Star Munchkin version since I love sci-fi. Mechanically classic set is pretty much the same. I keep this set around since it's localized to my native language unlike scifi one. Most of  the jokes are funny in childish way. I prefer to play with 45min timer.

RATING: 5

Less time to think adds to the randomness and hilarity of the game.

RATING: 5
Cutthroat game of dungeon crawling and backstabbing. Munchkin is a good 'warm up' for a night of gaming but not good for much else. There is a random amusing chaotic element to the game that is good for setting a mood to the evening but makes wider strategizing difficult at best. Many games end with a player ascending to ninth level, his opponents exhausting all of their offenses against him, and the next player to go for the win getting it as his opponents are out of ammunition to use against him.

RATING: 4
The cards are funny the first couple times you play it, especially when you understand the references (like The Gazebo). Other than that, it's a very poorly designed game that relies solely on the luck of the draw. Plus games can drag on forever. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Gets old really fast, and just lousy if one plays with people who don't play RPGs who won't get the inside jokes.

The game can be extremely punishing, as everyone will gang up on the leader, and this can go on for quite some time.

Other than that, this game is skill-free.  You will either get the cards you need, or you won't, and it will be painfully obvious when you do, and just as painfully obvious when you don't.  There is no tension beyond this.

Munchkin is cute and funny for about 10 minutes.  After that, exfoliating with a cheese grater is more enticing than continuing to play this mess. 

One my least favorite games.

RATING: 4
Good: 
Humorous artwork and card descriptions. 

Pretty simple game making it a perfect choice for introducing new gamers to the hobby.

I played this a lot in various groups of various different backgrounds. It was well received by pretty much everyone. 

Bad: 
The game has really simplistic gameplay that becomes extremely repetitive after a while. 

The endgame turns into a lot of take that to beat down the leader and king making. 

This is one of the games that is great when you are first introduced to the boardgame hobby, then when you see what is out there you don't really want to this again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Loved this game the one time I played it, though it was with pretty much the perfect group of players.  Might not work so well w/o the right 5 players.

RATING: 6
Immature, cutthroat, and cliche... but FUN and with TONS of player interaction. Players take on the roles of cartoonized fantasy fighters all competing to be the first to kill/buy/bribe/backstab their way to level 10. Lots of "dude, sweet" and "no you didn't" moments. This one is often overlooked, but when it hits the table, everyone enjoys it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This gets points for being really cute, with great cartoony artwork combined with funny card names.  The game is pretty interesting, but gets a bid ridiculous sometimes.  It pushes out all the depth of Dungeons and Dragons, leaving just the exploration excitement, and then turning into a war of words and making monsters really big, or screwing up your opponents in one way or another.  I'd rather play something less cut-throat, with more depth.  However, it is pretty amusing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Everything about this game is a blast and incredibly fun up until it's simply not anymore.

It has a great sense of style and humor with mechanics and gameplay that is immediately accessible if you're familiar with RPGs and quick to learn even if you're not.

You can have several dead draws which can hinder the early game quite a bit and bring it to a halt (though most of those cards have a "Get out of jail free" clause for low-level players), but it still is disappointing that it happens so regularly.

The end game, is where all of the fun quickly vanishes, as the "Screw your buddies" aspect of the game means that rounds become massive dogpiles of keeping everybody else from winning until somebody finally gets a lucky draw that can't be stopped or players have exhausted their cards to do so.

Even with that being the point of the game, it creates a lot of game sessions where feel-bad moments rule the day and most players leave the game feeling less than happy due to bad beats, bad luck, and/or a feeling of lack of agency.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It can be fun but often gets bogged down in the end game.

RATING: 7
This game gets a TON of hate for being what it is; a simple dungeon-crawler esque game meant for those who aren't too into either roleplaying or tabletop games overall! My experience with it: I like the game, though I do feel it is a little bit of a niche game. There is a take-that! element to the game, which is fine in general, but can get old after a while, and that seems to be this game's main flaw! While reviews and critiques can influence your decision, whether or not you should get this game is up to you to decide!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Le mécanisme de jeu de Munchkin se veut volontairement une traduction la plus fidèle possible d'une exploration de donjon basique. C'est un "casse-donjon"... sans le donjon. Le matériel de jeu est simple : une pile de cartes Donjon, une autre Trésor. Au début du jeu, chaque joueur tire 2 cartes Donjon et 2 Trésor, et créer son personnage niveau 1(en posant devant lui les éventuels cartes Race, Classe, Objet Magique et Pouvoirs en tout genre). Ensuite on commence.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A social game not-so-social.

Is fun to play with friends but has two main drawbacks: Some players can get angry or frustrated if someone goes against them. Also you can spend alot of time waiting for other players to finish their turn.

So, it's only fun if you play against your friends and try to mess in their turns.

Also, you will need some expansions to not get bored early.

The theme is silly and provides a little additional entertainment, but I'm always bored by the end of this game.

RATING: 3
As I've played more games (or even just reading more about games) I've soured on this. Reading the arguments against it just put words to thoughts I've had while playing. It's too long, there is too little agency and more.

It's my fear that Cosmic Encounter goes the same way with experience (it has already revealed some of the same tendencies), but it's more fun, gives you more to work with, and just on the whole a lot better - "strictly better" to steal a commmon term from MTG.

Just don't, play Cosmic instead if it is this type of game you are after.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Game in a Nutshell:  A light-hearted, dungeon crawl-ish card game where you fight monsters to be the first to level up to 10.

Played as:  4,5 player

Pros:  Has a good sense of humor all the way around. There’s some pretty funny items (slimy armor), monsters (Snails on Speed), and cartoon-y artwork (leather armor represented as a corset).  

Cons:  My biggest pet peeve here is downtime. Seemingly every card has necessary rules exception text on them (some much more than others) with no easy way to quickly separate that from the flavor text when you want to get to the point and keep things moving. It just feels like a big chunk of the game is sitting there watching other people read cards silently and figure out what they are.  If I could be contemplating a masterful strategic move in the meantime, I would be ok with that, which brings me to my second con... No real meaningful decisions. The biggest decision you need to make is if you want to be a jerk and drag the game on, or play nice and let it progress to an end. Outside that, it’s a lot of luck which can be absolutely brutal. 

Other:  I think I’m probably being hard on the game. It really should be more about the experience rather than a competitive event. What could really drag the game down are people who take it with one ounce of seriousness either by being butt-sore when crap is dealt to them or by refusing to cooperate to the benefit of all people. Again, this is less of a game than an experience. That said, the number of players I played with was too many for me. I guessing 3 players would fit best to minimize downtime, but still have enough people to make what little interaction there is interesting.   

Best Use:  The kind of game you’d bring out when you’re exhausted and have some time to fill without needing to be ultra-competetive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
El Munchkin es un juego "especial". Como la mayoría de los juegos de Steve Jackson. Y es que esta casa es capaz de sacar los juegos más originales y de temática más divertida "entre colegas" pero como casi siempre, falla en el sistema. El juego podría estar bien si no basara tanto su base de juego en la aletoriedad de las cartas, y hacer efectos tan descompensados, capaz de hacer que un jugador disfrute como un poseso mientras otro no pueda hacer nada excepto ver pasar los turnos. Un juego que viene bien para echarse unas buenas risas en momentos punteros de la partida (que por otra parte pueden ser gratificantemente divertidos). Pero nada más. El juego base "Munchkin" no está del todo mal. Quizá fue error mío el haberlo mezclado con las otras 3 expansiones que, al incluir más diversidad de cartas nuevas le daba demasiada vuelta de tuerca para principiantes.
"Chez Geek", también de Steve Jackson, posee un sistema de juego muy similar a éste, pero está ambientado en pisos de alquiler compartidos por frikis (al tener muchas menos cartas, se hace más rápido)
El "Fuzztoons", es la peor aberración que ha publico Edge y trata de imitar estremadamente mal y con sumo mal gusto al juego en cuestión: "Munchkin".

RATING: 3
This game is one of the very few games that started as a game I loved when I first got it that turned into a game I ended up despising as time went along... The constant take that and one-upmanship and being ganged up on detracted from what appeared to be a simple "kick-down-the-door" dungeon crawl type of game with a humorous bent, and while the game's look is still great after all these years and the humor on the cards is still there... I just can't stand this game.

It's not fun, not to me. Just not my style.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Весёлая игра для компании, с которой многие начинали. Предназначена в основном на ролевиков и D&Dшников (коих посредством этой игры понемногу перетягивают в настольщики), но благодаря большой популярности стала известна и среди простых смертных. Графика на картах выше всяких похвал - лучшего юмористического арта я пока не встречал. Юмор тоже в изобилии. А вот механика подкачала - за кажущейся простотой скрывается ужасный монстр из заплаток и подпорок. Если правила расписать по-честному, то они займут страниц 20. Для игры для новичков это должно было быть смертным приговором, но вот как-то не стало. Я уверен, что правильно в эту игру играет не более 10% игроков. Ну, т.е. правильно в неё играют только фанаты, которые регулярно посещают форумы SJG, общаются с волонтёрами SJG и участвуют в турнирах по Манчкину. У меня таких знакомых нет, а все известные мне лично люди, игравшие в Манчкина, играли в него неправильно (т.е. от "совсем-совсем не правильно" до "в целом правильно, но есть несколько серьёзных ошибок").

Меня в какой-то момент достало продираться в мешанине сложносплетений игровой логики манчкина и я в него больше не играю. А все 7 сетов и несколько дополнительных карт я рассматриваю исключительно как произведение искусства.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
When I first started playing Munchkin, I loved it. The inside jokes and clever plays on common D&D vocabulary had me rolling. While fun, the game can sometimes become interminably long, going on and on and on. And they always end the very same way: The front runner makes a play to win, everyone else blows their load to prevent it, and then the next player in line takes it without any real opposition. And there's no way to really prevent that mechanic from playing out. And is probably why most games take as long as they do: Everyone is fighting to NOT be the first to attempt a win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As a long time, old school D&D player I felt right at home here. This game took the essence of D&D and turned into a comedic fun house. It's satirical nature towards everything RPG-esque made this quite a reminiscent, delightful treat. I particularly loved Munchkin's take on the real life player interaction that unfolds during a real D&D campaign. It brought back old, fond memories. 

The mechanics were also pretty easy to adapt to a wider audience, and in addition I felt did a commendable job at keeping the player interaction on par with how an RPG should be. 

I've heard so many bad reviews on this game in the past from fellow board gamers but am glad I went with my gut and took a chance on this whimsical fantasy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is cool and I can see myself getting a lot of life out of it. Will need to invest in a few expansions before too long though or I think it might begin to feel a bit stale.

RATING: 5
Admittedly, I have not experienced the game with more than a smattering out of the multitude of expansions, but I think I get the gist. Its not my cup of tea, which, in this category, is Libertalia. 

 It is a very simple game that is paradoxically riddled with rule ambiguity (even Steve Jackson- the designer- screwed up the rules on Tabletop).

 If you or your group are way into *TAKE THAT!* style games, however, I would assert that you will probably enjoy this tea quite a bit, as the game seems to boil *TAKE THAT!* down to its bare essence.

 Edit: 
After more plays and expansions- its a good beer+pretzels game.

If you can't resist the humor, flip through the cards and satisfy yourself, but sitting down to a game of it is worse than unnecessary.

RATING: 9

RATING: 7
It's a unique game with it's ambiguous rules towards things like cheating and using random items you may or may not have to influence game play. This works for and against it in my humble opinion. It's really fun with the right group of people, but sometimes you get a few players that really abuse it and sap the enjoyment out of it for the others. Watch out for that and it's definitely worth playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game was frustrating at first.  The rules were confusing and seemed rather incomplete to even understand the basic mechanics of gameplay. We found some video recording on line of the creator just playing the game and after watching that for about 10 minutes, things got much easier.  Its really a great satire of so many of the ultra complex RPGs that just focuses on the good bits. Now that we have the rules figured out (we are probably making a few up and ignoring others, but who cares? We're having fun.) this game is in the regular rotation.  One of my favorite parts is that regardless of who gets the early lead, there is a pretty reliable pattern of behavior that the rest of the group gangs up on that person.  This leads to everyone really being right at the finish line at the end. It could be anyone's game just about every time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

Otherwise,unless cutesy jokey stuff is enough to float your boat the tenth time you read the card, pass on this.

RATING: 3
I'm not wholeheartedly against Munchkin. I just find that all of my games (with a crew of 5 or 6) always play out the same way; people ignore others leveling from 1 thru at least 5 and then they may be enticed to obstruct a leveler from 6 onward. Most of the time this builds to a situation in which 60-80% of the group achieve level 9 and are praying for luck to draw a weak monster card and steal the win. Usually it takes a few go-arounds amping up the challenging monsters to hold back a winner. After a few rounds, everyone is essentially out of enhancers and potions and the winner squeaks by on a weak monster who gains little help from an exhausted war party. It's not awful by any means, I just find it unexciting and slightly routine.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
No game stating "all rule disputes should be solved by loud arguments among players, with the game owner having the last word" in its RULEBOOK can be good.
This is pure mess, leaving so many subtle dependent rules on the players that I wonder why they bothered to have a rulebook in the first place.
That's not what game design should look like.

Other than that, loooong and boring random bunch of events with runaway scoring and bash-the-leader, where the only fun is from reading cards. Do yourself a favor, don't ever buy this, go to a teahouse, lend Munchkin, spend a few minutes reading the cards having laughs and then go play an actual GAME.

EDIT: Yesterday I watched it played again. Isn't that just annoying how players can decide to screw your cards and combos in YOUR turn, in the time when the control should be yours? I just wish the BGG evaluation could go below 0, to express what an abomination this is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I love this game for the shear goofy fun of it. The rules are quite simple, but the interaction of the cards make it a little difficult for younger kids. That is my only regret about the game--I won't be able to play it with my daughter for a few more year.  Still, one my favorites for pure entertainment.  Get a bunch of friends together and laughter will ensue.

I don't understand the loathing for this game by some in the community.  I guess some people don't like "fun", and it isn't serious enough because the strategy isn't deep enough?  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A classic dungeon crawl, comedy, group game, which has a cult-like following.  It has spawned several expansions and differently themed (same basic mechanics) additions and sequels on its way to several awards and a lot of money-making--who says the Wizards of the Coast has a corner on the card-set-expansion model?  Awards: Origins Awards Winner, Best Traditional Card Game (2001).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've played many many times to this game. We where 5 each time. It was long but very cool parties!

My advise is to never be more than 5 and to not follow the rule when you ask player help (the rule tell to ask each player one time and the first who want to help you just do it).

Just let players fights and threats them self to know if they will help you or not ("I can help you and I win one treasure", "No I wont this guy win the treasure so I can help you and you win all treasure". "If you do this I will make you combat fail with something I have! Or not..."). The only point is that YOU choose who will help you...

This create very long party but it's so fun! It increase interaction between players a lot!

I've never played so much with extensions. I've buy one (extension 1), we've played few parties with it but rules on extensions was so long/boring/difficult to understand that it completely break the game.

For me, Munchkin is almost a party game. There is no complex rules that's why you will not play days and days to it. But for the time you do, it will became good remembrances.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

However, buying expansions to freshen up the cards is practically essential...except that if you add more then one expansion in it completely brakes the game!

RATING: 4
PROS: 1. Fun (at first time). 2. Nasty, lot of interaction (but now I think that not so much)

CONS: 1. Random and chaotic. 2. Too long with wrong company (players, who like "thinking"). 2a. Some book-keeping slows down the game. 3. Twisted rules (and it's difficult to explain them to newbies). 4. The term "balance" is missing at all.

Best with 4 or 5 players. If fewer than 4, then it is difficult to downgrade the leader. With more than 5 it is too much downtime.

ISSUE: Fun at first time, but then -- boring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Like:[/b]
-Getting more powerful

[b]Dislike:[/b]
-No interesting choices
-Lots of cards with their own individual effect makes for long downtime
-Winner is the first who doesn't get blocked anymore

This is not the worst game ever like many people would believe you. However, it definitely doesn't deserve all of it's variants and expansions either.

There are a lot of cards that hinder other people, but there's really no point in using them unless someone is about to win, at which point everyone spams these cards they've been keeping up until that point. Some of the cards are pretty funny, but that only lasts the first few games. For non-board gamers, there's probably too much reading.

Overall, if there's nothing better to do I would play it, but usually, there is...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game has what I call the "Cards Against Humanity" effect. Your first few plays are really fun. The cards are hilarious, and the unique aspects of the game make it really fun to play - at first. After three or so plays, I knew most of the cards, and the game basically devolved into throwing tons of cards down only to have all the players gang up against you at level 8 or so and wipe you out. While it's hilarious at first, I prefer games where you have a sense of progression - building up your character as the game goes on makes you feel accomplished. I would much rather this game involve losing levels and some loot rather than staying at the same level and losing it all.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This has quickly become a regular play with my daughter and I. With two players it is a lot of fun but as with most games, the more players the more entertaining it becomes. Play is fast moving, rules are easy to understand and house rules are always an option (and many times encouraged)to add some spice to gameplay.

Have made it one of our travel games by using the 
phone app which includes level counter, dice and armor counter. Take the decks and wrap them with rubber bands and you are all set to play where you like for the most part.

RATING: 7
My first non-mainstream, tabletop game purchase. Eventually, however, the hilarity of the cards wears off and the gameplay gets a bit stale (we started waiting until about level 7 before screwing each other over), but it's not a bad game. (There's certainly much better ones out there.) It's been almost a year since I've played it last--maybe it's time to bring it back to the table (at least for one game).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In this card game that spoofs Dungeons and Dragons, players draw cards out of deck, which could be a monster, curse, race, class or other special cards. Players have to fight a monster, and get rewarded a level if they defeat it and get treasure. Otherwise they have to ask for help or try to run away. This game works since it is easy to play, and the cards are funny. There is a ton of luck as well, so if you are looking for an evening of laughing, and not take game play too seriously, this is worth a try.

This 2001 game has spawned a number of sequels and expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
The owner of the game store I frequent has expressed amazement that Munchkin continues to sell well at $24.95 MSRP when it's really just a deck of unlaminated cards and some rules.  After playing the game I am left with no choice but to assume that its fans are self-abuse experts with deep-rooted psychological problems that reinforce many of the negative stereotypes about gamers in general.  If you actually think that the trite and predictable in-jokes of "Dork Tower" and "Knights of the Dinner Table" are funny, and if you like games that have absolutely no balance and involve nothing but pure, blind luck and can easily last upwards of 90 minutes, then this mindless, overpriced, ill-conceived and barely-produced abomination should be right up your alley.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
First off, the artwork is excellent.  And the in-jokes and puns can be pretty entertaining ... for the first few plays.    But that's about where the fun ends - at least after a handful of plays.

The game itself isn't well designed, with instructions that are vague and unclear in many parts.  I've owned this for a long time, have played it ~20 times, but it's just gathered dust for the last few years.

Best use is as a "filler" while waiting for the rest of your gaming group, to be set aside as soon as you have a quorum. But you probably have several better games you could play instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
fun little game. want to get the post apocolyptic version because im not huge into fantasy theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The original!  This is one of our favorite games to play.  So far we've picked up every card expansion (still missing some promos and 'extras') and we love it!

Gameplay is fast and fun.  Players can team up for or against one another and often, in our games, the person who is currently in the lead will get ganged up on to prevent them from winning.

The only issue we've seen is that (like all card based games) it is possible - and usually happens to at least one player - to have really bad luck with draws. However, this is the case with a lot of games that rely on luck to get the resources you need to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Too easy to stop someone from winning. Games often took 3+ hours when played with gamers who played it straight, and games with others just went to whomever was most socially amiable. The game is 100% luck/social based, with minimal (if any) strategy.

The game also encourages players to cheat, and if you are playing with people who would do something like that, it gets very miserable very fast. I believe I also heard that there are tournament-legal bonuses you can get by buying other products by the publisher? That's just wrong on so many levels.

The only reason I still own this game is that I'm afraid if I throw it out, someone will pick it out of the dumpster and be cursed with it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Great theme, awful game. That avarages out to, well, avarage.
Makes fun of fantasy gaming in general, and D&D in particular. If you don't know anything about this, most of the jokes will be lost on you. And really, the jokes are what makes this game work.
Gameplay doesn't exist. You just draw a card and hope you can use it, most of the time you can't. Endgame consist of everyone attacking the leader, until people are out of cards so the current leader can steal the victory.

Eventually, the jokes start to get old, so:
Dropped the score: 6 --> 5.

Was a gaming café a while ago. Was asked to play a Munchking game (Zombies I think) and realized I really didn't want to do so. So: 5 --> 4.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
The biggest problem with Munchkin, outside of the base level of depth present in the game, is that the winner of the game is primarily the second person to make the attempt at getting to level 10. So when one person is fighting the final monster to win the game, generally people load up on their buff cards to make the monster win. That player dies, and all the buffs have been used so the next player is generally home free to win the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
One of my first games.  It can be a lot of fun when you are winning and downright awful when you are getting clobbered.  Luck plays an important role in the game but there is plenty of room for strategy.  My biggest complaint is the end game.  Essentially the person closest to winning can expect to have the kitchen sink thrown at them and it can be very frustrating.
