RATING: 3
Like so many other games that are supposed to be "fast and fun", this is a great game for the first 20 minutes. Unfortunately it easily takes 3 times this long even with only 3 players, and only gets much worse as you add warm bodies. 

After the first 40 minutes I find myself wishing that someone would just club me into unconsciousness to spare me the tedium. 
...and just when you think it's over, someone comes up with some silly card to stuff the lead player and keep the game going on and on and on. There are at least two of us in the group who will help someone else win just to end the damnable thing. 

Here's to hoping that this 'fad' will die out tomorrow...

RATING: 5.5
[WrenniePennie's copy]
Concept of helping and backstabbing works well in theory, but helping others can give too many advantages for the victor, and players with an obvious lead halfway through the game can be impossible to catch. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I love the humor in the cards for this game.  One of the elements I really enjoyed is how, as each player nears that magical level 10, the other players began to cooperate to thwart the current winner.  It leads to a very good, self balancing game.

UPDATE: I'm finding that Munchkin games are either really good or a total chore.  It all depends on finding the right group to play with.  If the players don't have a background in fantasy gaming or story telling, all of the humor falls flat.  It is even worse if the player doesn't have a history of video gaming, especially role playing games.  The concepts were totally foreign to my parents who struggled through half of a game before giving up in frustration.  My son is a big fan, but he really just wants to use the curse cards and cause pain to other players.  He'll use them even when it isn't strategically advantageous to him.  Once he runs out of opportunities to be the bad guy, he generally gets bored and loses interest.  On the other hand, I've played a few games with players with the appropriate background and only a moderate mean streak, and these games were a lot of fun.  Given this experience, I'm modifying my rating for the game from an 8 (based on the first game) to a 6.5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Light and fun. Not really made for 2 players but my one friend and I like to play this game while having a few cocktails. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
An over-hyped, bland card game desperately trying to be funny. 

The only reason people have any fond memories of Munchkin is they all won their first game. First-timers always win. The veterans blow their cards combating each other, while they take it easy on the newbie who then sneaks in a victory while no one else has the cards to stop them.

Boring, plodding, and long, especially with the basic starting setup.

Happy I offloaded this game on Craigslist.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b][center]In defense of Munchkin[/b][/center]
Ok, so here is the deal. I know this game gets a lot of slack on the geek and in other locations where board games are drooled over. Maybe it isn't the most refined game of all time, maybe it is a bit silly (well, yes in fact it is silly) and yes of course there is little strategy to be employed when everyone is back stabbing without reason.

But this is the game that took me straight in, it welcomed me to the world of collecting and the delights of artwork - particular thanks to [user=kovalic] for that. This was the game that I saw at a youth convention over someone's shoulder and the bug was caught. Maybe it is all nostalgia driven nonsense but I have great fun whenever we bust this game out.

We do implement a time limit though, the games do tend to drag on :P
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Masterpiece! Let's be honest, who doesn't enjoy infuriating other people?! I don't understand the BGG community - why is that game rated so low?!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
my INTRO GAME!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Only reason I'm giving this game a 7 is because I've had countless hours of fun with it. I introduced this to my campers at the Summer camp I'm working at and they literally won't stop playing. Everyone loves it. It's a great game to get kids into board games because it's simple, funny, and new players can easily win because the game is like 75% luck. If you're a seasoned gamer then look elsewhere. This game is silly, not really an actual serious game. Take a look at Cosmic Encounter if you like the interaction and backstabbing of Munchkin with a bit more strategy and depth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
We finished playing Taj Mahal and said, "We need a little filler game to clear the palate before jumping into something meatier."  Someone suggested a six-player game of Munchkin.

Two and a half hours later, someone finally threw the game.

I don't mind a little bit of "take that!" in a game.  Hell, it's what FFG is all about, Charlie Brown.  But it's like cilantro, in that a little bit goes a very long way, and for some people it tastes like dishwashing soap.  If "take that!" is part of your game's balanced breakfast, excellent.  If it's the only mechanism in the game and you're depending upon it for ALL balance issues, we've got a MAJOR problem, and Axe Cop ain't gonna save you.

I can admire a game that's gone through 19 printings.  It's found a wide audience.  And to quote Carlin, I ain't in it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
My first play wasn't bad, I felt it was just a goofy game and found it rather amusing.  My second game was absolutely horrendous.  We had someone try to explain the rules off the top of her head, and she wasn't sure of most of them.  This wasn't that big of a deal, but what made the game horrendous was her screaming at all of us (the rest of the players) saying we weren't playing it right.  Taking Munchkin too seriously?  Really?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A fun family game.  It's hard for me to rate because I know it's good, but I think people come to the same [or like] conclusion I have.  The game requires little skill or strategy and it's basically cards with stats on them and the person with the best stats and are the most agressive/focused win.  People who just like playing with the funny cards generally lose.  But hey, they win at having the most fun in my opinion.

It's not a game I bring to the table when I want everyone to have a blast and have a chance to really use their heads.

Munchkin is like Fluxx in terms of 'who cares, it's funny' games.  You get the same out of both.  Some theme, some laughs, and the winner is whatever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Amusing game, but painfully random, with no card balance.  Flip a card -- do you die, or gain a level?  Oh, you're about to win?  Do the other players have cards that can stop you, or don't they?  They don't?  You win!  Yay!  The only strategy seems to be convincing other players to blow their mailicious cards on other people so they don't have them when your turn comes around.  That cutthroat aspect is the only thing I do like about this game.

I sometimes play this one at conventions or events where I don't know people -- this is one of those games I never play with friends.

Yes, the cards are funny.  Once.  They'd better be, when you're paying 25 bucks for them (and nothing else).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A basic turn goes like this: "Open a door" (draw a door card face up for all to see). If there is a monster there, you try to beat it, if you can't, you try to run away. Beating the monster earns you a level and treasure(s). If there isn't a monster, you can either "go looking for trouble" (play a monster card from your hand) or simply "loot the room" (draw a door card into your hand).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It's basically Phase 10 with jokes and you can actually loose previous phases again so that it takes even longer.

I have played many games where I keep drawing equipment and never get to level up in a good fight...can be annoying.

I enjoy playing with the tiny Christmas expansions. It was fun to pull this one out a few days before Christmas and have a holiday dungeon crawl.

RATING: 8
We absolutely love Munchkin.  The game is easy to get into, and my kids absolutely love playing.  The only downside (for me) is that it can be a longer game than it's weight would imply.

Gameplay is really easy - open a door, battle a monster (maybe) and collect some loot.  Oh, and watch out for backstabbing buddies who are more than happy to invite some more monsters to your little party and then more than happy to offer to help you...for a price.

Fun to play, great game with a ton of humor in it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I really think 'Cock-Blocking' needs to be a separate game category on BGG.  You know, for the kind of game where a major focus is to screw the other players over.  That's the case here... and it's pretty fun.

Its a pretty simple game that even non-gamers seem to enjoy.  They say it can be played with 2-6 players but I'd recommend 3-4.  2 players will have balance issues and 5-6 can drag the game out.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun and light parody of dungeon crawl gaming. Play this for fun with people in the right mood and you'll have a great time. My wife enjoys this, but she is not a typical female, as she has also played wargames in her teens. We normally don't advocate games of this caliber, but I think Munchkin is swell.

Read the latest set of rules. 

Again, you shouldn't play this for a serious game, but rather for a fun social silly time. This is in the same catergory as Killer Bunnies and Fluxx. Every gamer should have a closet nonsense game.

Though we love Munchkin, we now prefer to play Fluxx because it is better 2 player.

Update- NYE 2012- NOPE! I had a 3.5 hour game that just.would.not.fucking.end and did not end, in fact, before we had to leave. 

I immediately burnt my copy in the fire-pit during the wee first hours of NYD 2013.

This game is *BROKEN* in that people who don't want to ever ever EVER quit can literally just keep the game going and going and going and going.

Take your Munchkin off my table and feck off with ye!

RATING: 9
Love this game! Personally I have the Deluxe edition and several extension packs. The game is always fun, but the concept is sadly hard for some to understand. Playing with people that aren't the best reading English makes the game slower and is kind of a buzzkill. Luckily all that changes with more "adult" players that understands the craziness. 
You will laugh, cry, swear and hug during the game. It is frustrating cuz of the very random gaming style... But that keeps is interesting.
Nonetheless is is my favorite game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is incredibly underrated and dismissed by more pretentious gamers. They are either too quick to falsely label the game as all luck or butt-hurt that it is mocking role-playing games, notably Dungeons and Dragons. The truth is there is plenty of strategy in the negotiations, by withholding cards in your hand and when you play them or go for levels.

Pros:
* Allows you to play a light RPG without investing so much time.
* Player interaction is great and creates a competitive but fun atmosphere.

Cons:
* The art work is poor.
* There should only be a deluxe edition, do not waste your time trying to play without the game board.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
divertidillo aunque a veces se hace repetidillo.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game introduced me a second time to boardgames - I stopped playing for at least ten years once I got fed up with monopoly and the likes...- it has nice humor, nice player interaction (dealing, double crossing, trading), enough simple and complex rules to keep beginners and the moderately strategist interested. The stand alone only gets better with the expansions. I have introduced this game to about 10 other people and all enjoyed the humour and appreciated the competition. Note about the bgg rating: I don't quite get why Munchkins has so many people who bothered to review it but gave it an average 6 score. A lot of top 500 games seem to have a lot less reviews (ie interest) but seem to shine a lot more simply by having a smaller and more loving bunch of reviewers. All in all, a unique game and a lot of fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1
Munchkin is a train wreck. I hate it. It's unnecessarily too long, there are no thought provoking decisions, it's completely random, and there is too much downtime for my liking. The worst part is that I see this game in stores all over the place and the general public thinks that this a good non-monopoly game. I cry a little inside whenever I hear someone say they enjoy Munchkin and all of its terrible expansions.

RATING: 6.5
6.5 - I've been unknowingly playing the last version printed before they overhauled the rules, the game is something I'm usually down for depending on the number of people who show up.  

I found out that the very next printing of the game after the version I was given as a gift updated the rules including larger starting hands, removing a lot of negatives that the newer expansion cards didn't seem to have, and clarifications of a bunch of rules that we had simply house ruled because there was no explanation.  I have printed the new rules and will be using them in my next game so the score may change.

*****
The new rules helped but the game is still a bit too long for it's own good.  I picked up the Adventure Time Munchkin and like that version enough to buy the board to track levels.  The odd thing is AT: Munchkin is the same game, but it doesn't feel as mean.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Iconic game that's a nice addition to any collection.

The game itself is a big whack-the-leader cycle where players will most likely take turns being the leader. There's a high amount of luck and randomness in the game, if you're looking for a strategic move along.

I really like the artwork and I find the puns and humor very funny. All in all I think it's a great party game that is particularly great for first-time players.

Weaknesses:

* Not as funny the second time since you've already seen all the puns.
* It's a bit long for a party game. I wouldn't mind playing until level 7-8 instead of 10.

Not a roleplayer, so a lot of the humour is probably lost on me anyway ... Not one for younger kids.

RATING: 4.5
Four reasons to hate Munchkin:

1. The jokes get old fast
2. It's too complex for non-gamers and not complex enough for gamers
3. There is a huge runaway leader problem, and the game is largely random
4. It takes way too long

One reason you might love it:
This game is off-the walls crazy.

RATING: 9
I've always been up for a nice round of in-character or board-game backstabbing and Munchkin is the one thing that lends itself to that... endlessly. The cardnames and effects get old very quickly, but it doesn't really detract from the fun of pissing off a few mates as they try to battle that lvl 4 monster that's now lvl 19, because you happened to have the proper cards. Sadly, the game mechanics are lacking for 2 players, so I will have to find more people to play with ;)

RATING: 6
A játék jellemzője, hogy erősen party-játék, azaz eleve több játékossal érdemes nekikezdeni. Az is fontos, hogy a játékosok valamilyen szinten fantasy rajongók legyenek, valamint ne álljon tőlük távol a humor sem. A Munchkin sajátos humorral bír, ami nem biztos, hogy mindenkinek bejön. Sajnos ezek alapján elmondható, hogy a Munchkin erősen rétegjáték.

Nem tudom, hogy csak a magyar verzió sajátossága-e, de nem valami jó minőségűek a kártyák, valamint elég hülye megoldás, hogy úgy kell mindent beleömleszteni a dobozba.

Lehetett volna két kártyatartó, vagy másfajta dobozos megoldás.

A játékszabály sem igazán egyértelmű, és így elsőre nem is volt tökéletesen érthető. Lehet jó lett volna valahol látni egy próbajátékot, hogy miként is kellene ennek működnie.

Frissítés 1: Egy picit módosítottam a véleményemen. Pár játékot le kellett játszani, hogy megértsem a felszín alatt húzódó "szépségét". Így 6-osra módosítottam 5-ösről az értékelést.

RATING: 2
Imagine playing Fluxx.  Now imagine playing Fluxx for hours because no one will let it end.   Welcome to Munchkin.
Munchkin is a party game that is too random to meaningfully influence with tactics or strategy, but not inherently unstable enough to play itself into a game over scenario without the players choosing to let someone win.  King making is all but required for the game to end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A very tongue in check type of game that pokes fun of fantasy RPGs. This game hasn't gotten stale for me, but I know that this is a very common problem for a lot of people.

There are 3 types of views on this game:
1)  You don't get the references and don't fully appreciate the game.
2)  The references are good for a few laughs at first, then gets old real fast.
3)  You really like the game.

My favorite card is the "Buckler of Swashing".

Own all basic expansions.

* Play on 7/12/07 was with every single other themed expansions * Two games, same style, 8/23/08 *
* 9/20/08 - original w/all 5 expansions
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Expansions:

Clerical Errors

De-ranged
Demented Dungeons

Promos:
Monster Enhancers
Reloaded!
Tricky Treats


Yes, it has problems, the biggest of which being how players will savagely attack anyone who is close to winning, which can cause games to be long and drawn out.  It also punishes those who are doing the best.  But other than that, its a very interactive game and can be a heck of a lot of fun with a good group of people.  It may have flaws, but is always a fun time nonetheless.
Full review here: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/808502/get-your-geek-on

RATING: 3
A classic that I've moved on from.

Hits this weird spot that a lot of lightweight games suffer from. Has enough depth for 15-30m of play, but because of the level ping-ponging, you end up playing for an hour longer than you care to. 

Holds a spot easily filled by other games, even in groups that aren't particularly game savvy. Would rather play a shorter lightweight (ex: We Didn't Playtest This At All), or an actual dungeon crawler (ex: Talisman).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Munchkin is a fun game and I enjoy the humor/spoof aspect of role playing games.  If you've never played before, by all means its something you should try and I'm sure you will enjoy.

 My only issue is after a few games with friends we all just started piling on to each other, so getting to the end of the game turns difficult at times.  I would still gladly play from time-to-time, but it's not the first thing I suggest on a game night.

RATING: 8
My wife and I are old-school role-players, and recently I have been trying to inject games back into my life. Unfortunately, it's hard to find fellow gamers when you're in your mid-thirties. After trying unsuccessfully to get her into Zombies!!! (not engaging enough for her), I went out and bought Munchkins after reading good things about it. Success! She loved the RPG related humor, and was eager enough to play again that I bought some more expansion packs. Say what you will, humor goes a long way to winning over the reluctant gamer. Now if they could just create a card game based on the old Paranoia RPG...

RATING: 6
Ultimately I have to go with the conventional wisdom on this game and its many variants.  The cards and artwork are fun, but the gameplay is so-so, and the games almost always end the same way:  

Someone gets to 9th level and makes a play for the win.  All the other players expend cards to stop him, and succeed.  Then the *next* person to get to 9th level and make a play for the win succeeds, because all the good cards were expended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Munchkin has offered a few nights of fun between different friend groups. The game, at it's core, is a social experience. While the game boasts as being a simplified dungeon crawling card game, it lacks in making me feel like I am.

What the game does poorly: Strategy is a bit of a joke. Most of the time you are hoping not to get some overpowered monster to ruin your day. Items are simple, but keeping track of what you and your opponents have can get overbearing at times.

What the game does well: Each play session is a test in who you should or should not trust. Alliances are made and broken in the same turn, and most of the time I felt like I was making some big negotiation just to defeat a monster, which was interesting. The art and jokes are silly and simple and the game does not take itself too seriously.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I would play it again.

RATING: 4
If you are a D&D guy that thinks that some people take their D&D a bit too seriously, you must play this game. It's not a totally cool, awesomely balanced game, but it's fun. And funny.

I knew I was in for something cool with Boots of Butt-Kicking and the first rule stating...

"To determine who goes first, roll the die and argue about the outcome and whether this sentence is missing some text"

Hilarious.

However, beyond that??? Look at the cards and have a laugh, but skip playing the actual game - you can thank me later for the advice.

Not a game for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Update on 2/18/2018 (4 -> 3): This game is irredeemable, and I suspected as much. 

The ever-growing line of Munchkin naysayers grows by one. All that was said was true: the game is a chore to play. It is a repetitive exercise in futility, rife with randomness, player elimination, king-maker. The fundamental flaw is when everyone has learned to horde cards until someone is in danger of winning. This will, as you might expect, delay the game to no discernible end until by some stroke of luck no one has cards to stymie the win. Such a situation is less likely to happen at high player counts with more hands to choose from to dole out death to the pending winner, which is unfortunate as the game itself thrives on player dynamics and banter.

(+) Loads of player interaction.
(+) Backstabbing, subversion, and guile are all the name of the game.
(+) Fairly straight-forward game sequence of play. Decent introductory-type game but nowhere near my gateway game of choice.

(-) An abundance of text to read throughout the game.
(-) An excess of cards that are designed to throttle the endgame scoring condition (and a faulty player metagame to complement it)
(-) Far too much randomness for my liking.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not fun game, anti-climatic and really frustrating

For a shorter version of that mechanism involving humour, I would much rather spend the time with Dr. Lucky due to its brevity compared to Munchkin.

1. The rules seem fairly clear and unambiguous (impressive for such a card game with zillions of special effects).
2. Often stupidly humorous text and art on the zillions of cards.
I played it once before years ago in Austin, then again at Gumowa Róża 2008-07-01.  Possibly once every few years is about right.

RATING: 4
05-06-2014. Commented after a while since last playing Munchkin. Well, I do not hate Munchkin. I do not think it's a very good game though. Lots of screwage, which I like. What I do not like is that the game tends to go long and outstays it's welcome.

The game provides some fun and backstabbery. The game is mostly luck-based. If you do not get items or easy defeatable enemies, you're in bad shape. If you do get those, you'll win. 

The end game often devolves in bashing the leader, due to which the guy in 3rd place often wins because everyone has exhausted all their options on the first two guys winning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.99
Have you ever fantasy role-played? Do you have a sense of humor? If you answered yes to BOTH questions, then give this card game a try. This game is a humorous take on fantasy adventuring where players sabotage each other until the very end. Not for players who tend to take things too seriously. Fun with a group of players who enjoy a good dungeon crawl, only this dungeon is filled with the hilarious, the absurd and everything in between! Players seem to either love Munchkin or hate it. Try it and judge for yourself.

RATING: 1

I couldn't stand the game so much that when the person who was ahead was going to win, I chose not to screw them over just so the game could end. I had a card to make the monster +10 levels and he would have dropped 2 levels and I may have ended up winning the game since I was pretty close. I just couldn't take the chance.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've only played the Epic version once, but highly recommend giving it a shot. Essentially, you draw two Door cards per turn, and go up to level 20.

At first, this seems like Munchkin, only twice as long. But, as you go past 15th level, it's much more difficult to stop players from winning combats. And, since you may have two monster combats in your last turn, players now must use their "take that" cards *two* levels before someone potentially wins.

Oh, and it doesn't hurt when you defeat two high-level monsters, draw six treasure cards, play two "Gain a Level" treasures, and go up four or five levels in one turn...! 

*****

To win at Munchkin:
a) Do not be the first person to attempt level 9 to 10.
b) Hold a low-level monster card in your hand.

I don't get how BGG, a strategy boardgames site, doesn't understand what should be a basic strategy. (BGG also doesn't understand trading in Chez Dork, nor the "advanced" rules in Spooks.)

I prefer the Munchkin Cthulhu alternate victory conditions. If all players are Cultists, the game ends and the highest-level player wins. But if only one player is left as a non-Cultist, he gains a level (even at 9th level) and can win. But, as more players become Cultists, each Cultist becomes more powerful. Heck of a balancing mechanism.

I also don't recommend Munchkin with more than four players. I also don't understand why BGG understands you shouldn't play Dominion with more than four players, yet plays BGG with more than four.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.67

Miguel: 6

RATING: 6
A cute little game; another Steve Jackson card game where most of the appeal is in the theme, and so once you've read all the jokes it loses a little bit of luster. The main problem game-wise is another perennial SJG issue: an end-game that boils down to "everyone play their screw-another-player cards until we're all out, then whoever's turn is next wins."

RATING: 3
Not really a good game. It's easy to teach at least, but it isn't really a fun game. It's only really fun if you like the humor. I do not like the humor. This isn't really a good family game, because some of the humor is a bit too adult for young kids. What little actual gameplay is there is mostly a series of "take that" style gameplay. It's fairly short at least. 60 min is actually about how long a game takes.

RATING: 8
This is a fantastically fun game but it can only be played with a group of like-minded players.  The goal of Munchkin is not to try to win, it's to try to keep everyone else from winning.  If that doesn't sound like fun to you then Munchkin is not a game for you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I thought this was really cool when I first played it, but also worried that there might be too much luck involved.  I was right about the latter, and now feel mostly wrong about the former.  This game is definitely filler material, which might be OK if not for the fact that it really lends itself to overstaying its welcome, due to the tendency of players to gang up on anybody who approaches the win.  This both prolongs the game and takes away the satisfaction of victory, since the winner will be the one who stood poised to win at the time when all other players finally ran out of means (which are just cards that create differences in combat scores; nothing clever) to hurt one another.  Thus, I'm left feeling firm that this is only suitable as a filler, and also not sure when exactly would be the right time to play this; if I can be sure I have time for this, then I probably have enough time to play something more fulfilling.  Even in the category of "Fillers that are sort of too long to be fillers and don't feel smart to play", I feel this is outclassed by Boss Monster.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Good as an every-once-in-a-while fun game, but far too random for me to play more than a few times a year.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Random as all hell, basically no skill involved whatsoever.  It's a chaotic, mindless, mess of a game.  I have to deduct points for that.  But I'll be damned if it isn't one of the funniest, funnest little games out there.  Well, as long as you have the right group.  As long as the guys and gals you're playing with know that the game is all about silly randomness and being a complete dick to the person next to you without really meaning it, Munchkin is awesome.  It has its limitations, hence the 6, but I'd still recommend it to anyone who enjoys this kind of whimsical murdery fun.

RATING: 2
Munchkin is a wretched grinding exercise in pain and agony.  Like pretty much every Steve Jackson game, it putts along reasonably until someone is close to winning, at which point it becomes an exercise in attempting to make the winning move and getting smacked down by screw-you cards until someone manages to get lucky by trying to win when everyone else is momentarily depleted (or simply sick of it and no longer care who wins so long as the game ends now).  The cards are funny to read, once, if you're fan of RPGs, and that's its only redeeming value.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Visual Appeal: (3)
The game looks OK. Nothing is a standout. Some of the art is funny, but that is the most it has going for it. Fits nicely in small play areas.

Components: (3)
It's really only cards. No issues here. They are of semi decent stock and rounded edges. Not bad but not pretty. 

Theme: (2)
The theme is standard, but a lacks complexity that I want for dungeon crawl RPG. There are tons of expansions that all seem more interesting, but since I don't care for basic game, I have no reason to try them.

Learning: (4)
This game is really easy to teach to a large group. everyone is going to be doing roughly the same things anyway. Actions are printed clearly on the card. I don't recall if I learned this game from the rulebook. I think this was a gift and I was taught by another player in my first game.

Gameplay: (2)
Not that the game doesn't have interaction. It does, but everything serves to slow the game down. To win you must level up, but everyone is constantly trying to level other players down. It can be targeted and outright mean sometimes. Usually I like that kind of thing, but I had one game so frustratingly long that I had to call it off. Mechanisms that make the game difficult by prolonging it are not good mechanisms

Overall Fun: (2)
When I owned this game, I remember it was a mood flipper. I went into it really excited and came out equally as disappointed as I had been excited. I think it has something to do with working hard to build up your score only to watch it be torn down by other players and relentless monsters. But, but, but...I need that to win! Or, to just end the game! When will it end if we can't progress???
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I used to love munchkin, but I'm just too burned out, and it goes way to long for what it is....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The best part of this game is all the silly puns and goofy art on the cards. Overall it's fun, if you like random games. It can drag on as everyone keeps thwarting everyone else from getting that final level. After a while you get tired of adding up bonuses over and over again.

Rather than rate every single Munchkin version, I am just going to state that I give them all a "7". So, to calculate the true rating of a Munchkin variant that I haven't explicitly rated, multiply the current rating by the number of raters, add 7, then divide by the current number of raters + 1. If you've played lots of Munchkin you should be able to do this easily.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Not a very deep game, but an enjoyable filler if everyone a) is in the right mood and b) likes D&D in-jokes. If you're a console RPG fan the level grinding and stuff collecting will really appeal to you. If you're not a die-hard RPGer, you probably want to give this game a miss. 

It's not as bad as it's made out to be, but way overpriced for what you get in the box (A$50 will buy you a copy of China, or an ASL Starter, or staying in the realm of overpriced card games with shitty components, a copy of Modern Art). Rules are poorly written also.

The bottom line is that for D&D fans it's worth playing now and then (too often would wear out the jokes), but probably not worth buying at the asking price.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is vicious riot.  Players take on the roles of "level one humans with no class" and the humor goes on from there.  The theme plays up the stereotypical dungeon crawl backed by mechanics that have you kicking down doors, killing monsters, and taking their stuff.  The first person to level 10 wins the game, but with all the backstabbing opportunities in this game it's not likely you'll get to level 10 without someone forcing some Bad Stuff to happen to you.  Players can interfere to help you (by distracting monsters or making them weaker) or hurt you (by adding monsters or making them tougher).

The lightness of the cards and the snarky rules help to alleviate the backstabbing pain.  Best played in larger groups of good friends who can be cruel without being mean.  Best played with people with a good and dry sense of humor.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Funny cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A hilarious card-game parody of Dungeons & Dragons.  Players represent characters collecting treasure, killing monsters, and back-stabbing their buddies.  The rules are simple and the replay value is quite high.  There are2 types of cards: Dungeon cards (monsters and effects) and Treasure cards (loot and other goodies).  The goal is to be the first player to reach level 10 by selling items, killing monsters, and playing certain treasure cards.  Knowledge of D&D and role-playing isn't required, but it does make the game that much more fun.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm sure there's not much to say that hasn't already been said about Munchkin. I enjoy the game, especially with an expansion or two. The artwork is fun and whimsical and there is plenty of humor inherent in the game. It's generally fun, light, and easy to get into.

My major gripe is that I always feel like the game runs too short. It's not until people are at level 9 or 10 that crazy card combos seem to come out and people really start going crazy buffing monsters or countering with items. I feel like it's more fun to play to 15 or 20 levels to really get the full experience of the game and the crazy card interactions that can appear.

I would definitely recommend an expansion or two though. More variety definitely improves the experience. I currently own Munchkin Booty and the Pathfinder expansions and I wouldn't play without at least one of them.

Absolutely terrible. Moderately funny cards, but the gameplay is awful. The game has a very low level of complexity that is not fun for the majority of the two-hour playtime. The game also provides the worst example of "bash the leader" gameplay in all of gaming. There is next to no strategy. You simply hope that everyone expends all of their cards keeping the person to your right from winning so that you can skate to victory. Probably the most boring and least fun game I've ever played.

RATING: 6
This game seems to get a lot of flak, but I love the corny puns and D&D jokes, and the game mechanics are pretty simple and easy to get a grasp on. The one problem I have is that this game is ripe for ganging up on the leader in a way that makes me never want to be the first to level 9. That element seems a little unbalanced, as I've seen people blow all their cards defeating the first attempt at level 10, only to see the next person fly through easily because no one has any cards left to stop them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Munchkin is a fun casual game, though its humor is geared at people who have some experience with RPGs.

This is a game that gets incrementally better with each expansion. If you're going to get the game, plan to get the add-ons as well. Just be warned that these add-ons will add a lot of extra time to your game. Munchkin can get pretty epic.

Or, try "Munchkin Bites" or "Star Munchkin," (with their associated expansions), both of which are much faster to play and just as fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The best part about this game is looking at the cards, particularly if you are an old D&D player like me.  Many of them are at least a little amusing and some are quite witty.  Unfortunately, you are then expected to play a game with them.  The game is an interesting (read amusing) reduction of an RPG campaign to a card game.  Sure it's pretty random, but there is some skill involved (particularly in regards to negotiation) with a fair amount of take-that, screw your neighbor stuff on the side.  As a half hour game, this would not be all that bad.  However, it is way too long for what it ends of being -- an exercise in seeing who can reach level nine and survive until no one has anything bad left to throw at them.  Winning is actually pretty anti-climactic after that. [5]
---------------------------------------------------------
Addendum: I've since played this with a less cutthroat group of players.  They are helpful almost to a fault, saving the beatdown stuff until people hit level 8 or 9.  This makes the game go a lot more quickly and thus makes it a lot more tolerable.  Still, it only bumps the game up to a 6 overall.  [02/02/2008]

RATING: 6
Appearance: 5/10
Mechanics: 9/10
Clarity: 9/10
Pieces: A few

This game is a lot of fun. Easy for new players to pick up and perfect for a party setting.

The artwork isn't that great, kind of a cross between Charlie Brown and some unheard of newspaper comic strip. What it lacks in beauty, it makes up for in humor. The names of the monsters and items can get pretty hilarious. The rules can be a bit iffy sometimes, but nothing so bad to slow down gameplay.

If you see it and have money to burn, pick it up

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[2010-09-05]
Az eddigi egyetlen rossz választásom társasjátékok terén a saját gyűjteményem növelésénél. Ezen elrettentő mondat után jöjjön a játék dicsérete. Kártyajáték komoly szerepjátékosok számára komolytalan kikapcsolódáshoz. Fantasztikusan humoros szövegekkel és rajzokkal megalkotott kártyák. Hősünkkel kincsek után kutatva egymás után rúgjuk be a kazamaták ajtajait. Társainkkal versengve próbáljuk minél több szörny legyőzésével leghamarabb elérni a 10. tapasztalati szintet. Ebben különböző módon a legrosszabb átkokat vetik be ellenünk és hatalmas pusztító szörnyeket küldenek ránk.
És hogy ezek után miért 3-as nálam a játék. Egyrészt kimondott konfrontációs játék. Az egymással való minél nagyobb kicseszés a játék lényege. Ez sajnos nem az én világom. Másrészt a játék a következőképp zajlik: Az első szintek elérése mindenki számára nyögvenyelős, mert a kis szintű szörnyekre várunk. Utána viszont mindenki gyorsan eléri a 8., 9. szintet, ahonnan viszont általában szerencsével lép fel valaki a 10-re.
Biztos vagyok benne, hogy a kiegészítők kellően színesítik a játékot és ezt a dolgot is kiküszöbölik, de mivel nem az én világom én nem próbálgattam.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2.5
The first one or two times this game is completely hilarious, but after you know the illustrations and names and start to get down to the game mechanics, it becomes a real pain. It is so unbalanced that it is not fun anymore (may be intended, but read it again to know why this is bad). You may be completely screwed if you get bad draws and can not do anything against it. If you just encounter traps and huge monsters there is nothing you can do while watching other people go on to win. If the game would be over after half an hour this would not be so bad, but it can easily take more than two hours. This definitely crosses the line for me. I never saw a game which so many people did not enjoy, the only one that has the potential to equal Munchkin in this area is Zombies!!!

RATING: 5
Complexity: Easy
Players: 3-6

Fantasy-themed party card game.  The quirky humor and interaction in this game is appealing. The problem is that this game often far overstays its welcome, ultimately devolving into a game of "last man standing after everyone unloads their cards to screw the current leader."  As a result, I think it's way too long for what it is, but I know some folks enjoy it.

RATING: 2
I have a near-hatred of this game and, by extension, all Steve Jackson games in general. I cannot [i]believe[/i] the number of expansions they've released for this thing.

The cards themselves? Moderately funny. Do yourself a favor: read through all of the cards then put the game up for trade, saving yourself the drudgery of playing a mechanically bland filler that goes on and on for-absolutely-ever since it's so easy to kick the leader in the teeth.

Edit: I played the sci-fi version with three players and it actually wasn't bad. I can't see playing with more players than that, though.

RATING: 8
A fun relaxing game. Don't expect much tactics apart from who you're going after (usually the one with the highest level obviously). The game is mostly about making partnerships, negotiating something for yourself if you help others and making the life of those high levels a lot harder. The cards are very funny and it's a relaxing parody card game, usually causes a lot of laughter and it's not that mean as it sounds, people usually don't get angry because you just boosted plutonium dragon to be lvl 42 or something. It's just a fun relaxing game and I like it a lot.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Munchkin is a profoundly flawed game that is immensely fun to play with the right crowd, in the right mood, at the right time.  It's also not the sort of game that holds up over very many plays.  Had I rated this after my first couple of plays, I'd likely have given it an 8.  Now, much later, it's just not the same.  Once you've exhausted the laughter, there's just plain better card games out there that remain fun (and funny) no matter how many times you take them out.  Lastly, for the typical MSRP, you're not really getting a whole heck of a lot -- bang for your buck is pretty low here in comparison with other similar games.  (Still a dirtcheap way to have fun, though, so I can't complain!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
I'm not into role playing games, so a parody of that genre might appeal to a certain group, but definitely not me.  Game drags on endlessly with very little decision making.  A few of the cards struck me as humorous and there is a small amount of strategy to elevate it above Fluxx-like status.  Hated it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I used to be a fan but my wife and many others in my regular game group were not.  As an RPG'er I loved the theme and enjoyed the cut-throat gameplay.  Games can sometimes drag and there can also be a huge kingmaker problem but I usually had fun with it.

That is, until I played similar yet much, much better games and I realized the only thing connecting me to Munchkin was the "in-humor" for RPG players.

RATING: 5
This is an annoying game for a couple of reasons:
1. For some reason it just seems to take way to long to finish. I always find myself thinking, "Ok this should be over soon." and then waiting 30 for it to finally grind to a halt.
2. Explaining the rules to new players is horrible. Absolutely horrible.
3. Too much text for too little payoff. Unless everyone already knows the cards you spend a lot of time sitting around in silence while everyone reads what they have.

How did I end up with three different versions of this?

RATING: 1
There is one sole reason this game gets a 1:  the owner of the game is allowed to solve any and all rules disputes by making up his own rules.  I played enough games of this where the owner made up anything he wanted to benefit him while screwing over the other players that I never wanted to play it again (read as one time).  Even before meeting this guy and playing with somebody who tried to follow the rules as written, it was pretty crappy.

RATING: 2
I've played RPG for several years, still like the odd fantasy adventure game (Like HeroQuest or Runebound) and I can even appreciate the kind of humour found in Munchkin. But alas, the jokes in Munchkin are funny only once, after which the dreadful gameplay, which seems to never end, starts to demand its toll. At 15 minutes, Munchkin would be a nice but silly diversion. At an hour, which it usually takes, it becomes the source of anger and annoyance.

RATING: 3

I think Munchkin stopped being fun around the same time that "random" stopped being the pinnacle of humor.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[SJ games 01 edition] {Beer&Pretzels, fantasy adventure; sabotaging; optimal 4-6p} Munchkin is humorous fantasy game. Good for players who like D&D or RPG but it's sad that I don't have many friends who like role-play adventure game. It's highly chaotic. 

The rules are clearly not thoroughly tested and written. I am not sure if Steve Jackson intentionally does it fun. The rules intend to and do involve many player interactions by the back-stabbing and helping. However, players tend to be very nasty and chaotic. The 'take that' element is strong. The game, thus, can last long. (the expansion cards somehow reduce this problem with more useful cards.)

Munchkin has heavy English barrier, it's not suitable for friends who don't like reading.

The graphics of the cards are funny and classic and they suit the game well.  However, it's unforgivable that the game does not provide necessary markers for the level and only comes with an ugly dice with such a price.

[Expansions] The expansion sets increase the replayability and humour. However, I don't like Munchkin Blender. If you don't like Munchkin, don't waste money buying the expansion cards as they indeed are expensive. I would not buy them if there was not a mega sale in a local game store.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Has yet to grab me.

(or much more with slow players or if you are playing with 6 or more players)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Casual 2-6 player party card game version of a dungeon crawler (D&D style adventure). Nice art with plenty of humour on the cards which brings the silliness of this game to life. 

Sadly the mechanics do not work very well, with 3 downsides: 1) there are not enough monsters in the deck (probably as an incentive to buy some of the many expansions) and its unlikely to draw ones appropriate to your level; 2) games can go on for far too long (hours); and 3) it is far too luck based, with repeated misfortune being frustrating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
old library - 2 copies
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Simple little beer and pretzels game - one of those where you shouldn't worry too much about the rules. Shouldn't be played too often, or it may get stale - the expansion packs help keep it fresh, though. Especially fun for old D&D'ers, but I've found that even "normal" people can enjoy the jokes in this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Things I like:

-Art. There is some fun derived from the comic style art, which is sneering at the fantasy genre. Some people might find this extremely entertaining, for me its funny the first time I see the card.

-Looting. Drawing loot cards is the most fun in the game.
You're getting reward cards that might be strong (which usually still helps next to nothing for your victory though).

Things I don't like:

-No variety. Basically the same cards are repeated (with different art though) over and over. There are not many actually different card types in this game. Keeps the game dead simple though.

-No strategy/tactic possible. It's all so random, basically Monopoly-random with more different things to see. There is next to no decision making, except the tiny part which hand cards to keep, if you should get multiple cards to stop someone from winning, which leads to this game's biggest flaw

-Stupid winning rule. A player wins when reaching level 10. Someone is level 1-8 when fighting a monster? Nobody cares, let him win the fight. Level 9? Bash him/her down with one of those overpowered "+10 for a monster", "put a second monster in the fight", etc cards. The worst thing is the fighting player is bashed by all others. After dropping some levels or losing some gear, this begins all over again. Drags on until someone is lucky enough that the other players can't bash him down enough (remember, no strategy/tactic involved here, it's draw luck) and is able to win the final fight.

I had to reread the rulebook but that's actually how it's supposed to be played. Don't know what the game designers thought when playtesting this. If those negative points don't bother you and you want to spend 60-180 minutes with this, get it. For anyone who's a bit into boardgames and not drunk, you should keep your hands off.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Humorous cards.  Flip a card.  If you're lucky you win or get free stuff.  If you're not lucky ask for help or maybe just die.  Keep playing until everyone exhausts their bad stuff then someone wins. There's more 'take that' and randomness than I like in my games.  Very social game. 2006/12/08
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The game is hilarious for the first few games but once you know all the cards it can get quite boring. Looking at people playing the game for the first time is a blast too, though. If you want to have the game exciting for yourself too, prepare to buy lots and lots of add-ons (because there are lots and lots of 'em!).

RATING: 5.9
this is a very light playable game, with some major issues.  the cards and the artwork are funny, it is fun building your character, slaying monsters and screwing over the other guy at the crucial moment but the game has some major flaws.  notably, you shouldn't play with more than five, even that is pushing it, it will seem like forever before it is your turn.  Also if you fall behind without using revised rules, it is nearly impossible sometimes to come back, which shouldn't be the case for a light card game.  But it is simple playable and not too heady.  Basically draw a card, use your carad and do what each card says.  Fun, but flawed.

RATING: 2
Haven't played this many times, so the humour value may wear off sooner rather than later. It's a luck-based disaster: There is nothing to stop you from drawing level 15 mosters on your first turn, nor to stop you coasting to an easy victory by drawing chains of level 1 monsters. Some way to scale monsters between levels would be great.

That, and some way to keep track of levels. 

The cards you get are a mess - invarably, somebody will be stuck with weak/useless cards, while another player gets lucky with their cards and wins. This is obviously the case to a lesser degree with a lot of card games, but it's prominent in Munchkin.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A mnemonic for roleplayers. If you've done RPGs, Munchkin can be a nice mnemonic for remembering all the times people did really funny stuff. As a game itself, it's not much, but at least it doesn't try to be.

Major rules flaw: the two-point-whatever seconds to play a card--not enforceable, so not a sensible rule. The rule to use is, everyone silently and secretly selects the cards they want to play, then plays them simultaneously. One chance to stop a win, or response, re-response etc.--whichever feels better to your group. Otherwise, you get into endless, "If you'll do this, I'll do that...." Better to just let the game end. Quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I used to like munchkin A LOT, and while I am still willing to play it from time to time, my multiple bad experiences with the game have made me dislike it more and more.  

The big gripes I have with it are:

1) The game can be very stressful when competitive players jump in with arguments starting since the game allows serious messing with your opponents.

2) The game can drag on making 1 worse

3) The game is typically extremely random with the player in first often getting last.

4) The rules aren't always very clear and one of the lacking pieces of the mechanics is that players can wait for others to help out in a shared fight allowing min-max players to sit back and keep cards in their hand.

These are gripes though, they don't mean I hate the game.  I just don't love it as much as I once did.  The art is great, and it can still be really fun with the right people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.4
I cannot express how much I love Munchkin. It's a brilliant game, full of luck and chance and malice between friends. Its easy to pick on the other players in Munchkin but it always (and I mean always) ends up coming back to bite you. Maybe too random for some and not really a game for those who want a mental challenge or to play something skill-based. For me, though, it's just the most fun I think I've ever had with a card game.

RATING: 6
A game much maligned by many other BoardGameGeeks, but I think it can be a lot of fun with the right group of friends. It's full of luck and backstabbing, but the mood of the game is so light-hearted and humourous that it is still enjoyable. Unfortunately, the game can run really long with a larger number of players, which the lightness of the game and limited appeal of the RPG-parody theme don't justify, and so you probably won't get a lot of repeat plays.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Chaotic, relies on theme and very, very tired humor. One of the writers for [i]Dungeons of Dredmor[/i] remarked that they checked that their jokes could withstand ten, twenty, fifty readings. Stuff that, if it wasn't still funny, was at least not grating. And so it goes that DoD has only released one expansion, with actual mechanical updates, where Munchkin has released what - dozens? - of vaguely different expansions and version, each focused on casting [i]animate dead[/i] because it's obviously too low level for [i]miracle[/i].

Munchkin is slightly redeemed by competent players -- the sort that legitimately play in Munchkin tournaments, if you believe those exist. Then the game can pass for being tactical. But if this is suggested out of the blue by your average gamer it's usually a sign that you're going to have a very annoying time in the near future. (Hint: The original rulebook explicitly condoned cheating, and enough of the fanbase took this seriously enough that subsequent printings had to go out of their way to explicitly retract that rule. [b]Illuminati[/b] shares this trait. I guess that's just what being hip looked like in the 90's.)

Many describe Munchkin as a fifteen-minute filler game that somehow crams itself into two hours, and I'm inclined to agree.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
This is one of my least favorite games ever. It's got some merits: goofy artwork, which some may like; a creative (for its time) and aggressive mechanic; can be played with many players, and some people really like it. I don't care much for the gang up on whoever is winning, and it becomes pretty difficult to win (mostly too long) if the cards aren't right or there are too many people. For me, the beginning is fun, but the game bogs down too much due to the lack of clarity in the rules, and basically being able to house rule many aspects of the cards. But that is just me, I have friends who really enjoy playing

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
This is just an awful game that got popular because people think they are "backstabbing" their friends.  Sounds cool, except it is just about building and breaking alliances as the game progresses, which is natural in most competitive games. So that is one attraction out of the way. You can get the same experience through Monopoly deal and Uno, which are sadly both better structured games than this is. Munchkin has no fixed rules. You spend time reading and deciphering the text, and arguing over it. You could and should cheat in this game, and that for me is a deal breaker. If a game cannot have discernable rules and requires a third party (in this case the owner of the game) to decide who gets their way or how something should be implemented, then you are better off just arm wrestling to 10 victory points. The artwork is great of course, which is the only reason I can think of for its popularity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A humorous take on the silly bits of fantasy roleplaying as a card game, and a typical Steve Jackson product - it's fun for a while until you've seen all the jokes at least once, but mechanics-wise it's very light, and a bit confused too - and, worst of all, it can take forever. 6 as a game, 9 as a piss-take on RPGing (and I did my fair share of that in my time, so this is an educated opinion).

RATING: 4
Underrated on BGG, however the game will only succeed with an excited and willing group. Not a brain burner, just pure fun and action. Do not expect a lot of strategy. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
This game has more luck than a leprechaun on St. Patrick's day.  For someone who likes strategy games, this is too random for my liking.  Ya, the cards are kinda funny the first time you play, but aren't funny at all anytime after that.  No wonder there are 2,000 different expansions for this game; the cards get old fast.  The gameplay is so broken, basically, someone gets close to winning, and everyone teams up to bring them down, and the game keeps dragging on and on until someone gets lucky enough to win.  It's a game that should take 30 minutes and can take 3 hours.  Now, you might say "Well, it's funny to screw people over and it's a light party game, not meant to have a lot of strategy and not to be taken too seriously".  But, there are 1,000 better party games that are more entertaining, more fun, and take less time than this game.  There is no niche that this game fits into well.  It seems like this is the game that people own who have only played American games (like Monopoly or Risk) and think they are special for owning it, and have no idea of the better games out there.  Awful game, and have no desire to play this again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
I hate choosing a 1 for a game so many of my friends love, but it's true that I wouldn't be caught dead playing this again.  I've even given it several tries.
The artwork is funny, the items are funny, I do like the idea of mixing 'space' and 'cowboys' for Space Cowboys.

The problem lies with the actual game.  You spend the first 45-60 mins getting to level 9 (level 10 wins), then you spend the next 60+ mins attempting to just beat 1 monster.  The game becomes "Ok, I'll defeat this monster.  Oh, Jim just made him harder, ok, I'll play this card to get stronger.  Oh, now Bob played a card to make him harder, ok I'll play this card I've been saving to get stronger and beat him.  Oh, now Ashley is playing a card to make the monster stronger and now I've lost.  Well that was dumb.  Ok now it's Jim's turn, oh we all played cards to make him not win so now it's Bob's turn." REPEAT.

The winner is whoever is after the player that go so close to winning that everyone spent their 'take that' cards and now don't have any to stop you.  That's it, just whoever goes AFTER the guy who almost won.  They don't have anything to stop the next player and he wins.  Such a waste of time.  It's the first time in my life I walked away from a game (90 mins in an we had all been at level 9 for 2/3 of the game).

I'd rather play Monopoly, in fact, I'd rather do anything else before this, including calling it a night.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is loads of fun, and simple to teach.   

If you've ever played dungeon and dragons, or any similar type of game, you can really appreciate the humor of this game.   The art in this game is hilarious, and the play on words just keeps you wanting to draw more cards.   I own pretty much all the expansions, and this game is the single reason I was able to get my wife into boardgaming.

If you're looking to have fun with a bunch of friends over beer with light conversation, this is the game for you.  If you're looking for strategy, and skill based challenge?  Look somewhere else :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I don't mind luck in games, there is something else about Munchkin.
I will not refuse to play, but it is guaranteed that I won't enjoy it unless it ends very close. This happens so infrequently because it depends on too many factors (player characters not being over/under-powered, encountering monsters that are beatable, even distribution of "take that!" cards, etc.)
I find Munchkin unbearable/depressing at its worst, and when close it still comes down to "take that!" cards, which is not really fun.

Plenty of games of Munchkin have left me unable to level up towards victory because I don't draw enough creatures, beatable or not. But I have also won plenty of games that just weren't fun. I remember one game where I climbed levels over two or three rounds, then immediately won by selling off all my cards. Even the card played to drop me down a level couldn't stop my victory. Never have I felt more like I've wasted people's time with a board game.

Needs refinement to ensure more reliable gameplay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
One of the first games (along with Pandemic and Catan) that got me started in this hobby two years ago.  I like Munchkin for what it is - a goofy fun time.  The game is otherwise very limited in decisions and really random.  It also encourages the "gang up on the player who is currently in first" ideology which I despise.  This cheapens the game and makes it seem pretty random who ends up winning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

I enjoy playing it, we as a group enjoy playing it.  Munchkin is silly, and easy, and a good source of inside jokes.  I think those are all hallmarks of a good game.

RATING: 5.75
Unlike most board game fans, I am fine with Munchkin. It is a good game, but only if the players are in the right mood or mind set. The game only really breaks down when players are trying to win. If a group is going into the game with a goal of hurting each other as much as possible instead of trying to be the winner, the game can be funny.

Having said that, the humor on the cards is light-hearted, it is not side splittingly funny.

RATING: 7
My opinion after one play, it was much as I expected: a very simple and abstracted dungeon delve, with lots of player interaction, mainly of the "take that!" variety, though there can be cooperative play for mutual benefit, but only up to a point, since everyone is racing to be the first to level 10.  The biggest draw is the comedic art and text on the cards, which along with the screw you factor means this game would be a blast with the right group.  This is very light and strongly luck based, but played quickly so didn't outstay its welcome.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[b]Munchkin[/b] has jokes that don't resist many plays. The gameplay is lackluster, prone to luck. There is a good deal of take-that elements that can lead to some funny moments, but also frustration after sucessive failures to do basically anything. The biggest sin of the game is the lack of playtime control, so a game that shouldn't take more than 30-45 minutes (at the most) to end, can take 120 minutes or more.

The artwork, by [b]John Kovalic[/b], is the best part of [b]Munchkin[/b]. But, save yourself some time and go see the [b]Dork Tower[/b] comics.

The 4 rating reflects the artwork and the games that end up in less than 40 minutes - these ones are berable and the theme/humor can keep me interested for that long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Where the game would never end at the final level because whoever was 1 monster away from winning would be interrupted and this would repeat until either a random person won or the discard pile got shuffled and the process got repeated.

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
This game. 
It's like Mario Party without the mini games. You just press A until bowser comes out and gives the bonus star to Luigi for no conceivable reason. 

It's simply not for me. 

The artwork is so offensively poor I wish I could unsee it. The quality of components is about the equivalent of the packaging you discard after buying a real game. 

I hate it. It is pointless but not benign. It's actually a waste of time and that is not a matter of taste in games. This is a literal commentary on the morality of doing nothing. This game makes me feel like I'm going backwards.

Everytime I hear someone say it's name with joy or curiosity I can hear the flap of black wings in my heart as the Dark Crow of Mourning comes to rest upon my fears and squeeze them tight. 
I feel like this game makes it harder for me to introduce people to the hobby because of how underwhelming and unsatisfying it is. You can have fun playing it. Once. If you seriously have nothing better to do and very open mind.

The term Gateway can be thrown around to try and help justify it's market presence and accessibility but I believe there has to be a better way of getting our hobby to the wider world. There are better games that can introduce people to the hobby.

This game is unwelcome in my collection and will never again seize my time and stuff vast amounts of it down the drain of life. 

But hey.  If you play it and it works for you, hooray. I don't mind that it does good for the hobby, I just mind that it does bad too. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I'd make fun of this game, but that might be considered Looking For Trouble.

RATING: 5.8
Fun to play with your buddies, overpriced card game. Game is oriented around negative interaction, and your so-called friends, will always try to screw you up. It's not really complicated, however, rule book is written terrible, and it makes you feel like this game is really complicated. No, it's not, really.

Game itself is not challenging. It's about screwing everyone and everything up. If you like this kind of negative interaction, then you might like this game. But for me, this game is medicore at best.

RATING: 4

RATING: 4
When Munchkin first hit the people I game with, we had fun.  Then it became the game we had to play every time.  Then came 5,000 expansions, each one making the game longer and harder to win (Super Munchkin being the worst of this) and people often wanting to mix them up.  This is probably my second favorite, and the one I'd play if asked, but only very rarely.  Games where you have to try hard not to be winning are not a game I want to play anymore.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
The Cult of Munchkin is an odd thing: the first time you play, it's kind of fun. Whimsical, even. 

After a few plays, however, the honeymoon is over. There is no semblance of balance or strategy in this game- you can sandbag and/or bluff, but that's about it.

Being entirely luck-based wouldn't be that terrible, were it not for the fact that it can take 3 hours to finish if playing with 4 or more players. Expansions only add to the misery. How can a supposed "beer & pretzels" game drag on that long?

The best part of the game is the nomenclature of the cards, followed by the accompanying artwork. If the game itself were as good as these, it would be fun to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
It's beyond belief that this trash has somehow accumulated a cult following. I had always thought this game was very old; from the 80's at least. This was a comforting thought, because this was the reason I told myself it had fans. It was from an era before civilization had figured out some modicum of game design.

However, this game is from 2001. That's still pretty early when thinking about modern boardgaming, but consider the fact Puerto Rico came out the year after this.

I had a point there but I'm having trouble formulating thoughts when realizing that this game isn't even from the 90's and it's literally worse than every other board game we all love to shun. Battleship is better. Clue is better. MONOPOLY is better.

Where do I even begin with this? Firstly, the outcome is completely random. Players may argue that it has social aspects akin to Catan, but it doesn't matter. There is no strategy. There is no gameplay.

You'd think a game based on pure randomness with no gameplay would be simple to explain, right? I mean, everyone knows Rock Paper Scissors. But somehow this cretinous game not only completely fails to explain any rules, but it actually relishes in doing so. It even deliberately fails to explain "who goes first", the very first segment of the rulebook. Every single turn made results in an argument about rules, which is pointless because none of it matters. Someone could win with their opening hand. Someone could be given no cards to allow them to win during the duration of the game. Someone could be given all the cards to win in a single turn, in an ultimate example of kingmaking. The game promotes "stabbing your friends", but there's often situation where you aren't even allowed to do that. Or you might be, but the rules aren't clearly explained, so who knows?

The only way this game's existence makes sense is as a giant troll attempt. If Steve Jackson had made a bet that he could make the world's worst card/board game and make it profitable, then congratulations sir, you have done it. 10/10, successful troll is successful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[gameid=172933].

RATING: 3.5

RATING: 3
A game I very much regret wasting money on.  I got a "McGinty Guest Artist Edition" which is technically a deluxe since it came with a board.  I think the good stops at the guest art and board.

I really couldn't wait for the game to be done.  It felt very stupid and pointless.  It's all luck.  You draw cards, draw more cards, and draw more cards.  If you're lucky, you'll level up and move up the path.  If not, you might lose your gear or get knocked back down a level.

This game sounded good and it was recommended by many people so I had to try it.  Boyfriend didn't hate it as much as I did, but I have no desire to play again.  It seems like it would be better used as a party game - with a larger group of people (probably involving alcohol), but is not a game for the 2 of us or even our families.

Ulmer
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I have played this game a few times now, and that's enough for me. The humour probably makes each version worth playing once or twice, but there's an incredible amount of chaos. Being a (former) roleplayer heavily into fantasy themes, I get all the jokes, but this game would be painful for people who aren't.

If you die, you start back at 1 with no stuff, which is incredibly annoying - even when it happens to others, since if they win the game would end! If this game took 30-40 minutes, it would be a nice filler, but unfortunately, a game can take anywhere from 30m-2hr. By the end of a long game you wish there was player elimination so you can go watch TV instead. It doesn't help that the game is also quite expensive for the quality of the components.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
I have played one game, where the others had played this quite a lot. They said that the game is easy, fast and fun and didn't even bothered to explain me the rules nor show the different types of cards. Of course, if you are familiar with something, it is easy to you, but for a newbie it most likely is not. I learned quite a lot during the game of course, but the overall feeling was not that good. Second time with better preparation might be better, but I still think that this game is not my favorite genre. Not much to do, lots of player interaction and the game just lasts and lasts...

Update after second play, no, the game is not for me. It is "funny", but not enough, and the end game is just too long.

Updated after two more plays. Still way too long (although we had too many players as well), but now I managed to understand the rules and develop some tactics (I won both plays). We used Star Munchkin and Cthulhu Munchkin expansions. Updated the rating from 4 to 5. I don't think I will play this game anymore, if there is more than 5 players...

Another play, with 7 this time. Over two and half hour with just the base game. It had some fun moments, but it is just so long...

RATING: 7
This is a very fun game.  Basically it is an RPG using cards with a high degree of "stick it to ya!" for everyone playing.  It is easy to explain and quick to play.  One of my favorites when the gang needs something quick and light weight.  The game is really about just having fun with a fairly high silliness factor.  If you are looking for a deep strategic game experience, this is not your game.  But if you would like to find a game that you can play quickly and just blow off steam with some buds, this one is worth giving it a spin.

RATING: 6
I've played the original game half a dozen times but feel it is not one I'll choose to play regular;y as it does lend itself to 'runaway victories' unless everyone chips in to prevent the purchasing of levels and retrieving add level cards from the discard pile. The game art is very atmospheric, and to be fair, it is a game that for all the skull-duggery, is very tongue in cheek as players try to play beneficial cards for themselves. These may be racial and class types or item related ones that give bonuses. The threshold level seems to be about seven levels when the 'tit-for-tat' wandering monsters kick in. Like many games of this kind, every player should be looking to prevent a runaway leader which may mean keeping hold of level bonus cards until later on. I think it plays well as an occasional game but does drag on sometimes so I think an egg timer would make it run a lot quicker and make it more manic which i think is what the designer wanted.

RATING: N/A
Munchkin is a stand-alone card game designed by Steve Jackson that "simulates" (well, sorta') a fantasy-themed RPG (oh, ok, DnD) in a simple, card-based game that's chock full o' silliness. Everyone begins the game as a 1st level Human with NO Class (heh-heh) and via cards, they acquire Races (Elf, Dwarf, etc.), Classes (Thief, Wizard, Cleric, etc.), Items, Armor, Potions and more that they use to combat hideous monsters like the 4th level Undead Horse, the 10th level Net Troll and the 14th Level Unspeakably Awful, Indescribable Horror (very nasty, indeed). The object of the game is to reach Level 10 and levels are acquired via the slaying of monsters and the selling of acquired treasure (1,000 Gold Pieces equals 1 Level). Very silly and a lot of fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Needs 3 or more players, and they have to be of sufficien maturity level to play
