RATING: N/A
Kill the monsters - Steal the treasure - Stab your buddy. Munchkin is a stand-alone card game designed by Steve Jackson that "simulates" (well, sorta') a fantasy-themed RPG (oh, ok, DnD) in a simple, card-based game that's chock full o' silliness. Everyone begins the game as a 1st level Human with NO Class (heh-heh) and via cards, they acquire Races (Elf, Dwarf, etc.), Classes (Thief, Wizard, Cleric, etc.), Items, Armor, Potions and more that they use to combat hideous monsters like the 4th level Undead Horse, the 10th level Net Troll and the 14th Level Unspeakably Awful, Indescribable Horror (very nasty, indeed). The object of the game is to reach Level 10 and levels are acquired via the slaying of monsters and the selling of acquired treasure (1,000 Gold Pieces equals 1 Level). Very silly and a lot of fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
After numerous play-throughs, This is a great set of jokes and a horrible game. Each game essentially devolves into holding all of your actually good cards (the ones that basically say "you can't win this fight") until someone who's level 9 is about to go out, and then playing one. You repeat this until everyone is out of delay-the-game cards and someone randomly wins. It sucks.

But it's even worse than that. When someone is about to go out, you don't want to use the card to prevent them from winning - you want someone ELSE to use a card so that they can't use it on you in the future. The result is a slow-ass waiting game where people stare at their cards, hemming and hawing, until someone finally gets bored and prevents the poor sod from winning.

This is also another in the long line of "player who pulls ahead first can't ever win" games. The person who tries to go out first inevitably gets the pants rocked off of them.

One variant I've been tooling around with in my head is to allow people to go out with the "level up" cards. This would in theory fix the horrible waiting time at the end, and encourage people to use their cards early on leaders rather than much later. I haven't had a chance to try it, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Overrated
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Have The Last Laugh, Pegasus Steed and Mystic Correspondence Promo(?) cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
С аддонами, расписывать не буду.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I usually enjoy the first play of a Munchkin game. The silly card combos and inside jokes make suffering through the tedious gameplay bearable. I can't honestly say that there is technically anything wrong with the way the series plays...I just have a personal dislike for adventure games that rely upon opposing players to disrupt fights and pump up the bad guys in order to provide the challenge. I don't like it in Runebound or A Touch of Evil and I really loathe it here. Not only is it frustrating to never know what you need to actually win, it usually makes any game that utilizes this mechanic last far beyond its welcome. Again, I completely understand Munchkin's popularity. It's an entire deck of RPG geek culture references. It's just that as a game, I find it really boring (especially after the jokes run out...) and far too long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The game is really good because you get to battle monsters.Its great when you have luck.

RATING: 4

RATING: 2
I started out enjoying this one, but it only took me four plays to reach my burnout point. Munchkin is a VERY long game that is at least 90% luck. If you get dealt a bad starting hand? Tough luck. If you constantly draw random cards that don't help you? Tough luck. 

Games with 5-6 players can easily go to the four hour mark. In the late phase of the game it becomes a complete stalemate with everyone playing cards that prevent each other from finishing the game. I actually sabotaged my last game and helped another player win just to prevent us from going into a fifth hour of Munchkin. Never again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
Munchkin can be fairly amusing, in that its a great satire of role playing games and gaming in general. The problem with the game is that, true to its theme, it encourages everyone to play like a munchkin. There are constant rules disputes, min/maxing, and pound on the leader problems, meaning that the game can drag on and on and *on*! After one 3.5 hour long session, I decided not to play it anymore. It's a lot of fun to listen to other people playing, though. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
players: 3-6
best with: 4-5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
As a game that doesn't take itself seriously, Munchkin succeeds - as long as the players can follow suit. It's very good at being what it intends to be - an opportunity for people to be power hungry and merciless to each other.

The sometimes ambiguous rules combined with the encouragement to argue your stance (no matter how far-fetched they may be), erratic power fluctuations, and obvious or non-existent choices can get old pretty fast, but if you want a game where everyone just slugs it out, Munchkin works.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
For a while this was easily a top 10 game for me.  I enjoyed busting down the door fighting the monster, and grabbing the loot.  This game was interesting to me and I love how simple it is to play.  I mean we got to the point we would play this game EVERY chance we got.  It got to the point that I would try to save all of my good cards for level 10.  Why do you ask? Because That's the level everyone pulls out all of their baddies on.  Then after countless times of play I realized... THERE IS ONLY ONE STRATEGY!! EVERYONE saves ALL their good cards till that last level and then its an aftermath into which usually the next person to reach level 10 ends up winning.  Now, I'm not saying this is a bad game, I'm just saying for the amount of times we played it we eventually broke the game.  Which is why I bought an expansion to this game to see if it changes this game up someway.

RATING: 10
I've been playing with a friend's set and borrowing it to play with other friends, and every single time someone new is introduced to it, they go buy it as gifts for all their other friends. :D I am a table-top RPG and MtG gamer, and Munchkins scratches both itches at the same time, in a very light-hearted and accessible way. I can play it with people who would never touch D&D or MtG. It's whimsical and doesn't take itself too seriously, but the rules are an elegantly balanced work of art. There isn't much storyline (unless you add it in on your own), but the mechanic is so fun that it feels like there is one.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
"Kill the monsters - Steal the treasure - Stab your buddy."

Munchkin is a simple card game that parodies a Dungeons & Dragons RPG. Everyone begins the game as a 1st level Human with NO Class and via cards, they acquire Races (Elf, Dwarf, etc.), Classes (Thief, Wizard, Cleric, etc.), Items, Armor, Potions and more that they use to combat hideous monsters. The object of the game is actually to be the first to reach Level 10 by slaying monsters and selling acquired treasure.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
If Munchkin could just make the game end instead of it dragging on forever once someone hits level 9 I would like it so much more because I like most of the mechanics and the art. But when a game that should be 30 minutes starts to break an hour, it wears on me fast.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Munchkin is tons of fun for the fantasy gamer. Kovalic's illustrations (Dork Tower) are the perfect match for the utterly ridiculous nature of the game itself.

This is a great game, full of valuable life lessons, like "Never pick up a duck in a dungeon, ever." (Remember that one, kids, next time you cross paths with waterfowl in your local dungeon!) Plus, it allows you to learn many useful trades. (Like the rogue, who can backstab any character.) And you can try a variety of races, and change race often. (The dwarf is nice, if you're a packrat who likes to carry extra stuff. Or be an elf, and get rewarded for helping your companions.)

Seriously, it's great fun. And it works best if you have friends who can get into the spirit of the game... "Kill the monsters. Steal the treasure. Stab your buddy."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Though initially fun, replayability is hampered by the relatively unbalanced nature of the cards in the base deck.  Moreover, the endgame very quickly devolves into an archenemy situation, with all other players at the table collaborating to stop the leading player from actually being able to seal a victory.  

A decent party game, better if the novelty of its cheeky puns hasn't yet worn off.

RATING: 6
I used to play this game a lot, but as time goes by this game grew a bit stale on me and the kingmaking 'everybody pile on the winner' so that the runner up can win the game is a sad part of this game. 

The card art and naming and themeing is witty and funny at first, but the humor quickly wears of.

Best rule of this game though is that if no-one sees you cheating, than you are not cheating. This can create an interesting dynamic within the group, but can also grow tedious is someone constantly and overtly cheats the whole game through.

RATING: 5
Hilarious game... once or twice. Mostly a "Screw the leader" dicefest kind of game. If someone starts to win, everyone gangs up on him. As a result, the game-- drags-- too-- long. Playing time 45 minutes? Yeah, right. The two games I played lasted 1.5 to 2.5 hours. The cards are very funny to read through, but not funny enough to mask the broken and un-fun game below it. I rate this about a 3 for a four-player game or more, and about a 6 for a three-player game. It plays much better with fewer players.

RATING: 3
Rulebook made zero sense. Game was ridiculous and involved total nonsense. Owner had no idea how to play the game and said there was meant to be a game board and pawns which were non existent. Something went awfully wrong when they pulled this out, because I hated it and was left with a terrible taste in my mouth. The very first paragraph of the rules referred to tokens that were not included in the box. This is probably why I always practice my own games at least once before pulling them out on friends and trying to teach them. Would never play again based on this one bad experience. On my first 3 turns all I did was pull curses. Then on my fourth turn I instantly won the game through level up treasures from beating 1 monster with a chainsaw and some other bonuses and modifiers. Total garbage.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A true beer and pretzels game- or perhaps, given the context, Mountain Dew and Cheetos. Munchkin has an underdeveloped system that compensates by throwing ridiculous situations and an ever-increasing supply of customization and new mechanics into the mix (they could compete with M:tG for most new sets released in a given point of time).

If you're looking for a light, relatively quick (20-30 min at double standard life, so about 15 min on average) game, and you can be appreciative to the genre (and the inside jokes the game makes against it) and the vast supply of webcomic artists that contribute to the game (and will fill in blank cards at conventions) then Munchkin is a necessity for your collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

My wife despises this game so much...  ANd I love it so...

RATING: 2
REALLY LONG for what it is. This game should take maybe 30 minutes, being that it is at heart a card drawing, dice rolling game with no board and no long-term strategy. Instead, it often takes 90 minutes, and can go as long as 3 HOURS. Unfortunately this is the syndrome of every Steve Jackson game I have played. I will refuse to play this game every time it is suggested, as well as any other SJ games. Maybe they should focus more on gameplay and less on 'humor'- or at least what they try to insist is humor.

RATING: 6
This is not a game to play with thin-skinned friends, or people that don't like being dog-piled on.  The humor is good, though after a number of plays you know all the humor, so it's not as funny and you'll likely be buying the expansions to add humor into the game.  Yet, the rules make picking this game up very easy and enjoyable.  For anyone that's ever thought they would like to play a casual RPG game, but didn't want to be bothered with the pen, paper and voluminous rule-books; it's RPG-very-light.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
When I first saw Munchkin played at TableTop - Wil Wheaton, I was enamored and said to myself I must have it. And now that I have it. I wished I should have not gotten it at all. It's a good game yes. But there is so much stuff that makes it a tad boring than your normal take that type of game. When I said boring it's because the game overstays it's welcome in a gaming session. The biggest selling point and achilles hill is it's mechanics of being able to pull your opponents down the same way they can pull you down from achieving victory. At first this game is a novelty of negotiation, alliances and betrayal. But this same novelty wears pretty quickly once the game time moves over an hour. All in all this game is good for at least 1-3 plays. Then you can definitely store it somewhere in the darker parts of your shelf.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Great on its own but expansions offer fantastic bonuses. A clever comical send-up of all things D&D with near unlimited potential to be constantly expanded with more monsters and items. Very tactical and interactive despite the sillyness. Will appeal to ANY age group.

CONS; Requires a minimum of 3 players and recommended no more than 6. Player can easily gang up on others (regardless of lvl difference or advantage) meaning best played with people who love free-for-all competition and will not seek to let others win.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've heard complaints about this game, but I really love it. The cards have a lot of humor in the names and illustrations, and the game play is very light hearted and full of betrayal. Still, this is a game that, more than most, depends on the group you play it with. It is not a very strategic game. Rather it is purely a negotiation game where you are playing the people more than the game.

If you play with a group that has problems with betraying people and stabbing them in the back, then this is not the game for you. Everyone at the table has to realize that nobody is their friend and have fun with that, otherwise the experience can be ruined.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Munchkin isn't *great*, but it is lightweight and easy to play with casual players. Unless I am with serious gamer friends, this is easier to get on the table than most. I do prefer different versions; people who are willing to play the mock-D&D version are willing to play something closer to D&D, less fluffy.
